sections.heading: 1. INTRODUCTION
sections.text:
The first biosensor concept was published in 1962 by Clark and Lyons1 and demonstrated the use of the Clark oxygen electrode as selective transducer for the detection of an enzymatic reaction, i.e. the oxidation of glucose by glucose oxidase (GOx). Since then, glucose biosensors have become the most studied and commercially most viable on-site, overthe-counter, rapid diagnostic tests. Still today, more than 50 years after its initial conception and its many advances, research is going strong, pursuing sensors that reliably detect glucose in tear fluid or can be implanted together with an insulin pump. The same success story is needed for a myriad of other analytes that often are more difficult to detect as they are available in significantly lower concentrations, as no equally excellent and specific biorecognition element (BRE) is available, or as the matrix may be yet more demanding. Nowadays, biosensors have become a valuable tool in a number of applications beyond the well-known glucose sensor. These include monitoring of treatment and progression of diseases, environmental monitoring, food safety concern, drug development, forensics, and biomedical research. In some cases, analytes in samples can be directly detected by the sensor unit without the need of sample preparation, for example, the online monitoring of hazard chemicals in disposed wastewater and cell-based bioassays. On the other hand, some samples may require more complicated preparation processes in order to isolate and/or enrich the target analytes with minimal interfering species prior reaching the sensor unit that ultimately enhances analytical performance. Lab-on-a-chip (LOC) is a platform that allows these modules to be integrated (Figure 1), providing a robust automated system for desired applications. This review discusses the possibilities functional nanomaterials can offer to the development of improved electrochemical biosensors and their associated LOC systems. Nanomaterials were already used long before the term was coined and before it became trendy.2,3 For decades now, colloidal gold has been the standard ingredient of most commercial lateral-flow tests, liposomesalso termed nano-
vesicles these daysshowed their superior signal generation capabilities in electrochemical sensors already in the 1990s, and enhancement through silver deposition was used for analytical purposes already in the 1970s. Thus, what kind of nanomaterials are synthesized today that are presumably so special for electrochemical biosensors and LOC devices? Which inherent properties do they offer; which chemistries do they make available for required functionalizations? How are they applied in biosensors? The ultimate question to be asked is, are they truly useful or can bulk materials provide the same result in the end when all optimization has been done? To facilitate readers’ insightful understanding on how functional nanomaterials can be beneficial and effectively implemented into electrochemical biosensor-based LOC devices, seminal studies (often publications older than 5 years) are comprehensively included. These provide important fundamental basics regarding device fabrication and critically relevant information on nanomaterials. So that the reader can find answers to these questions, this review is structured as follows: In section 2, electrochemical biosensors are defined, described, and put into context with respect to their analytical use. Material choices, immobilization chemistries, and biorecognition molecules are briefly discussed. Further described are the various electrochemical transduction principles and possible assay formats. Typical application areas are presented. In section 3, the same information is provided for LOC systems with special emphasis on material choices, and the added analytical capabilities offered by the miniaturized systems such as sample preparation and on-chip detection. In section 4, chemistries offered by the nanomaterials that are of interest to the analytical systems are discussed in detail. The focus is on metals and metal oxides, the various carbon nanomaterials and conducting polymers (CPs). Section 5 is the heart of the review. First, in section 5.1, an overview is provided of nanomaterials and nanostructures relevant to electrochemical biosensors. Zero-dimensional (0- D) to three-dimensional (3-D) materials and nanoarrays are included here. This subsection includes an important table
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.8b00172 Chem. Rev. 2019, 119, 120−194
121
(Table 5) in which the nanomaterials are further summarized with respect to electrochemical performance, function, improved property, and where applicable and available. In section 5.2, relevant example publications from 2013−2018 are discussed in detail, and an enhancement factor in comparison to non-nanomaterial based approaches is given. In section 6, the review finishes with a discussion of remaining challenges and future directions. Electrochemical biosensors and LOC devices have to provide a large variety of analytical capabilities so that analytes can be detected specifically within a complex matrix. There is no limit to the variety of sample matrixes and the nature of the analyte for current and future developed analytical systems (Figure 1).
2. ELECTROCHEMICAL BIOSENSORS
2.1. Definition
A biosensor is a device which contains a BRE that interacts with an analyte from a sample leading to a chemical/physical property change, which a transducer converts into a measurable signal. Moreover, an electrochemical biosensor according to IUPAC is defined as “a self-contained integrated device, which is capable of providing specific quantitative or semi-quantitative analytical information”.4 It should be noted that most DNA or protein biosensor-based electrochemical detection reported in the literature typically refer to “sensing systems” or “(bio)analytical assays”, involving discontinuous operation steps prior to data acquisition (the top loop in Figure 1), rather than “true biosensors”, acquiring information continuously (the bottom loop in Figure 1).5

sections.heading: 2.2. General Layout
sections.text: The biochemical receptor, such as an antibody, nucleic acid, enzyme, cell or receptor molecule, is ideally retained in direct spatial contact with an electrochemical transduction element (Figure 2) and must meet strict requirements with respect to sensitivity and selectivity toward a target analyte especially when contained at low concentrations in complex sample matrixes such as blood, food samples, or wastewater.6 Electrochemical signal transduction can occur through the measurement of current, potential, conductance, or field effect and is realized in either a label-free or labeled approach. Catalytic BREs, such as enzymes and cells, can produce electrochemically active products and afford, therefore, direct electrochemical detection. In the case of affinity BREs, labeled and label-free approaches can be realized in which nanomaterials play a fundamental role not only as labels but also as electrode material.

sections.heading: 2.3. Electrode Materials and Their Performances
sections.text:
A variety of electrode materials ranging from noble metals to carbon to conductive polymers is available to enable specific biosensing applications. Noble metals (platinum, gold, silver) are often used due to their excellent conductivity and superior electron transfer kinetics. Moreover, those metals also possess a high stability and (except for silver) inertness. Since gold lends itself well to microfabrication and immobilization strategies, it is a highly favored biosensor material that can be used reliably between −0.1 and 1.3 V.7 Mercury, the most common electrode material in polarography, has limited applications in biosensors due to its inherent toxicity.8
Semiconductors such as indium tin oxide (ITO) gained much attention as electrode materials as they are cheaper than noble metals, transparent, and easy to process. Their potential window is larger than that of gold (−0.4 to 1.9 V). However, ITO has a significantly lower conductivity (104 S cm−1 vs 107 S cm−1)9,10 and is unstable in acidic environments.7 Also the electron transfer kinetics of ITO are typically worse than those of noble metals or glassy carbon.11,12
Carbon based electrodes include a variety of materials divided by the respective hybridization of the carbon atoms. Graphite, from simple graphene sheets to highly oriented pyrolytic graphite (HOPG), contains sp2 hybridized carbon atoms, whereas diamond is made up by sp3 hybridized carbon atoms. For the latter one to gain higher conductivity, doped diamond structures are developed, e.g. boron-doped diamond.13,14 Glassy carbon is one of the most popular carbon materials for application as an electrode as it can be easily processed and has a large usable potential range (ca. −0.4 to 1.7 V).7,15 Carbon electrodes are known to work best with organic redox molecules, but a major drawback is their inherent reactivity, which may cause problems with nonspecific reactions in complex sample matrixes. Electrodes made of CPs such as poly(3,4-ethylenedioxythiophene) (PEDOT),16,17 polyaniline (PANI), or polypyrrole (PPy)18 are typically chosen for offering mechanical flexibility or optical transparency. Yet, their conductivity and electroactivity typically are worse than those of noble metals and carbon materials. Also, long-term water stability can be a problem.19 The properties of the discussed electrode materials are summarized in Table 1.

sections.heading: 2.4. Electrochemical Biosensor Detection Strategies
sections.text:
2.4.1. Potentiometry. In potentiometry a potential difference between two half-cells (reference electrodes, REs) is measured. No current is flowing. The most prominent potentiometric sensors are ion-selective electrodes in which a membrane provides for the ion-selective response. The concept can also be used for the detection of gases and
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.8b00172 Chem. Rev. 2019, 119, 120−194
122
biomolecules.20,21 In most cases potentiometric sensors are chemosensors; however, when combined with a bioselective separation process they can also be assembled to be full biosensors.22 In field-effect transistors (FETs) the same principle is being applied through the measurement of ions present in the gate electrode area of the FET.6
As discussed by Jiri Janata in 2012,23 there has been a renewed interest in electrolyte-gated field-effect transistors; however, serious controversy exists with regard to the validity of FET (bio)sensing. Janata points out that the nonpolarized nature of, e.g., graphene/electrolyte interfaces does not allow direct measurement of interfacial charges albeit claimed by numerous FET biosensor publications. He proposes a small number of control experiments required to demonstrate actual FET sensing of the analytes rather than reporting likely measurement artifacts. The inclusion of FET sensors in this review does not imply their endorsement, but they were chosen as these introduce interesting and relevant functional nanomaterials. The readers interested in FET sensing are referred to Janata’s publication from 2012 for an in-depth discussion of this controversy. 2.4.2. Voltammetry. Voltammetric techniques are typically based on the application of a potential between a working electrode (WE) and an RE. A current is flowing and measured between a counter electrode (CE) and the WE as a result of reduction/oxidation processes at the surface of the electrodes. In its most simple form, a constant potential is applied and current is either measured at a specific time (amperometry) or integrated over a period of time (coulometry). Various more
sophisticated approaches vary the potential over time to obtain better signal-to-noise ratios (such as differential pulse voltammetry (DPV) and square-wave voltammetry (SWV)) or to obtain analytical information on the redox reaction (cyclic voltammetry, CV). It can be a reliable method to determine analyte concentrations, reaction kinetics, diffusion properties, the size of an electrode, etc.24
2.4.3. Impedance Spectroscopy. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) is performed by monitoring the impedance, a frequency dependent resistance, after an electrical stimulation (voltage or current) in the ac mode. Some mathematical calculations are necessary to evaluate experimental results in comparison to an equivalent electrical circuit. EIS can deliver on the electrochemical characteristics of a studied system, which can be conductivity, reaction rates, dielectric constants, or mass transport.25,26
2.4.4. Conductometry. Based on Ohm’s law, conductance is the inverse value of resistance measured in dc mode. The resulting sensors are often referred to as chemiresistors and typically serve to measure conductivity changes within the bulk of an electrochemical cell, for gas sensing or enzyme-based strategies.27−29
2.4.5. Stripping Techniques. Stripping techniques involve an analyte preconcentration step raising the following detection to high sensitivity levels which makes trace-level analysis possible. After preconcentration the molecules are stripped off the electrode by electrochemical oxidation or reduction. The stripping analysis includes a variety of techniques related to voltammetry or potentiometry broadening the range of applications.30−32

sections.heading: 2.5. Integration with the Biorecognition Element
sections.text:
According to the stringent IUPAC definition of biosensors, the BREs must be in intimate contact with the transducer. However, oftentimes, BREs can also be immobilized within other areas of the biosensor, or are not immobilized at all. In most instances, though, an appropriate immobilization strategy must be found that results in a highly functional and stable BRE that can provide specific reactions with the analyte. Typical strategies include adsorption/physisorption, covalent binding, membrane entrapment, embedment in gels/hydrogels, physisorption of thiol groups to gold, and combinations thereof. The standard chemical methods with the most important advantageous and disadvantageous characteristics are listed in Table 2. Furthermore, immobilization via biological functions can be achieved through histidine tags, biotinylation, DNA tags, and antigen tags.33 New strategies also include specific peptide

For example, cellulose binding domains can be used to create fusion proteins or to immobilize whole living cells. The application of cellulose as a substrate is beneficial for developing biocompatible systems as it is inert and biologically degradable.34 Examples of other successful bioaffinity tags are given in the review by Terpe.35

sections.heading: 2.6. Biosensor Assay Strategy: Labeled vs Label-free
sections.text: Label-free electrochemical biosensors can monitor the biological reaction that occurs upon BRE-analyte reaction/binding directly. Examples include impedance and potentiometric based sensing, which are mostly performed label-free. Typically, these methods use DNA hybridization,36,37 aptamers,38 and also immunoassays,39 depicted in Figure 3, but also molecular imprinted and enzymatic approaches are done. Voltammetry-based techniques can be employed for label-free assays where the electrochemical signals are generated from oxidation or reduction of intrinsic electroactive components of (bio)analytes, e.g. nitrogenous bases in nucleic acids,5 and amino acids in proteins.30 In addition, the alteration of a BRE’s conformation driven by the binding of analytes that subsequently influences the accessibility of redox probes can be used. Alternatively, the label-free approach may not be feasible, not sensitive enough, or not appropriate for a chosen transduction principle. In these instances, different strategies are employed in which ultimately a label provides the electrochemical signal. These can be typical sandwich assays,40 sensors utilizing molecular beacons,41 or electrochemically active DNA intercalators.42 The respective strategies are also depicted in Figure 3.

sections.heading: 2.7. Current Most Prominent Application Fields of Electrochemical Biosensors
sections.text:
Electrochemical biosensors are employed especially in areas in which in-field, point-of-care, or on-site sensing is necessary as they are easy to miniaturize and the required hardware is inexpensive and reasonably simple in comparison to optical approaches. This includes health care, food analysis, food safety, environmental monitoring, bioprocess industry, and
biomedical research, among others. The simplicity of the required hardware combined with an inherent sensitivity resulted in early commercialization of electrochemical biosensors such as the glucose sensor, e.g. the i-STAT (Abbott Diagnostics), and biological oxygen demand sensors.43,44 In contrast to optical sensors, electrochemical biosensors can be employed in sample matrixes with high optical density, can easily be implanted and remote controlled, and offer minimal material costs. Typical examples are analyses in blood, serum, saliva, and urine;45−47 sweat and tear fluid are more recent developments.48,49 Future objectives are the commercialization of implantable and wearable sensors, e.g. temporary tattoos, or wearables such as contact lenses, eyeglasses, and mouth guards.50−53
In food and beverage analyses, bacterial contamination and toxic ingredients are of greatest interest, but many biosensors are also available to determine food ingredients such as carbohydrates, alcohols, carboxylic acids, biogenic amines, or adulterations such as antibiotics, herbicides, or pesticides. One of the current trends points toward the rapid, in-package determination of food freshness.54
In the case of environmental monitoring, long-term stability, autonomous systems, and wireless communication strategies are of greatest interest. Early examples included pesticide monitoring systems using flow-injection approaches (without wireless transmission)55 and today include the detection of microorganisms, organic and inorganic pollutants such as pesticides, dioxins, hormones, aromatic compounds, antibiotics, toxins, and polychlorinated biphenyls, metals, nitrate, and inorganic phosphate.56 Trends point also toward the detection of safe drinking water and determination of communal parameters in wastewater.57−60

sections.heading: 2.8. Dealing with Challenges of Real-World Samples:
sections.text:
Avoiding Interferences
Each analytical technique is only as good as it is in avoiding false-positive and false-negative results. The conditions that interfere with the BRE in electrochemical biosensors are the same as for any other biosensor system. Further concerns are those components that directly interfere with the electro-
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.8b00172 Chem. Rev. 2019, 119, 120−194
124
chemical transducer. This can be divided into two categories: (1) electrode fouling and (2) nonspecific signal-producing reactions with the transducer. Electrode fouling refers to unspecific adsorption of molecules from a sample solution that leads to a blocking of the electroactive surface, which results in a loss of sensitivity and selectivity and can ultimately lead to false-negative signals. Some electrode materials allow (electro)chemical cleaning or polishing of the electrode surface for reuse; however, typically it is advisible to prevent the electrode from fouling, e.g. by electropolymerizing a protective film on its surface, protecting it with a membrane, or preblocking it with defined molecules such as bovine serum albumin (BSA).61,62
Nonspecif ic signal generation is caused by molecules of the sample matrix that undergo electrochemical reactions with the electrode and hence produce false-positive signals or misrepresent the concentration of actual analyte in the sample by providing a higher signal. This makes the quantification of the target analyte difficult and is typically more problematic in label-free assays. General strategies to avoid any type of interference include sample pretreatment to remove most of the undesired matrix molecules before the actual measurement, avoid unspecific interaction by means of a blocking agent, such as BSA, or by membranes/coatings on the electrode, which repel interferants by electrostatic interaction or permeability.63 Much research is required (as for any other analytical method) to ensure specific signal generation, and much research has been published about avoiding interferences.64 In the case of voltammetric sensors, a general trend is to use low detection potentials, and in most electrochemical systems ionic strength and temperature must be paid attention to.

sections.heading: 2.9. Biosensors Require High Stability for Long-Term Analyses
sections.text:
Electrochemical transducers provide typically an inherent longterm stability, and little specific care has to be taken to ensure functionality throughout storage. Instead, in most cases longterm stability is determined by the BRE associated with the transducer and not by the transducer itself. However, electrode fouling must be controlled or cleaning procedures evaluated for long-term use. Here, noble metal electrodes typically outperform other electrodes as simple chemical and electrochemical cleaning procedures are available. Glassy carbon electrodes (GCEs) are regenerated through polishing procedures, but electrodes made of screen-printed surfaces or organic polymers typically lend themselves better to single-use. Microfabricated electrodes can also suffer from detachment upon high current flows and extreme potential uses and have a significantly more limited lifetime than macroelectrodes.65
3. ELECTROCHEMICAL LAB-ON-A-CHIP SYSTEMS
3.1. Definition
LOC is a device which is capable to scale down laboratory functions to a chip format up to a range of only a few square centimeters.66 An LOC platform integrates and automates different laboratory functions. For analytical LOC systems, as here reviewed electrochemical LOC, the term “miniaturized” or “micro total analysis system” (μTAS) is often used as a synonym. Manz et al. defined μTAS as a total analysis system performing all sample handling steps extremely close to the place of measurement.67

sections.heading: 3.2. Design of Lab-on-a-Chip Systems
sections.text:
As LOC systems enable the complete analysis of a sample, the components of each system are chosen according to the analysis. Usually LOC systems contain microfluidic channels for the transportation of the sample. In addition to the microfluidic system, several functionalities are combined on an LOC system according to the analytical problem. The most important features integrated into analytical LOC systems are sample preparation, separation, and a detection system.
3.2.1. Materials and Fabrication. Fabrications of LOC systems from a variety of materials are reported (Figure 4 and
Table 3). The first microfluidic devices were fabricated with inorganic substrates such as silicon or glass. With ongoing research and increasing popularity in the field of microfluidics, polymers became the most common substrate for the fabrication of LOC systems. More recently, LOC systems based on paper have been described. Three main factors have to be taken into account when designing the microfluidic system: required function, degree of integration, and application.68 A brief overview of LOC materials with respect to their characteristics and fabrication techniques is given in Table 3. Each material for fabrications of LOC systems has its pros and cons (shown in Table 4) that have to be taken into consideration for proper applications. Excellent comprehensive reviews about the fabrication of microfluidic chips have been published recently.68−72
3.2.2. Integration of Sample Preparation. When handling real samples, a variety of the sample characteristics can disturb the detection. Typically, interfering species, complex matrix effects, or nonspecific binding affect the detection signal in a negative manner up to a disabled analysis. One strategy to reduce matrix effects and unspecific binding is
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.8b00172 Chem. Rev. 2019, 119, 120−194
125
the coating and blocking of the microfluidic structures. When coating and blocking is not sufficient for the required sensitivity, two pathways are possible to obtain the same sample preparation as available during the benchtop approach. Microtechniques can copy macrotechniques or microphenomena can be exploited.91 Reviews with more detailed microfluidic sample preparation were published recently.91−94
For several miniaturized preparation techniques such as filtration, extraction, purification, and enrichment, significant progress is reported.68 Yang et al. developed microfilter membranes based on paper for the separation of plasma from whole blood with results comparable to those of conventional centrifugation methods.95 Solid-phase extraction (SPE) is used for purification and enrichment of samples. Together with other processes such as separation and detection, SPE can be integrated into LOC systems.96 Reversed-phase, using silica columns, and affinity SPE are the most common ones used in LOC systems. Monolithic structures for reversed-phase SPE can be directly formed on the chip by UV polymerization of butyl-, lauryl-, octadecyl-, or 2-hydroxyethyl methacrylates.68 Acrylate polymers also are reported for their application in on-chip SPE.92
Immunoaffinity monolith is integrated in microchip electrophoresis for extraction and separation of preterm birth biomarkers directly from a human serum matrix.97 The use of magnetic bead based preconcentration is widely applied as an immune affinity interaction preconcentration method. Cleanup of the sample as well as preconcentration is achieved when the magnetic beads exhibit high affinity to the analyte.92 The immobilization of analyte molecules and the following cleanup enable full control about solvent-specific parameters such as conductivity, pH, and ionic strength. Other preconcentration techniques applied to LOC systems utilize analyte characteristics such as charge, affinity, mobility, and size. Electrocapture can be used for preconcentration and cleanup of the sample by applying an electric field on a conductive membrane.92 Other preparation and separation techniques based on electrophoresis are widely applied to LOC systems.68 Porous membranes and a variety of nanomaterials can be used for a size-dependent sample preconcentration (see also section 5.2.1). The lysis of cells in LOC systems can be performed with the same lysis efficiency as in the macrosystem using a miniaturized magnetically actuated bead-beating system.98
For the cell separation and concentration, various techniques exploiting microphenomena that lead to comparable results with benchtop approaches are reported. Cell separation was performed using the Zweifach−Fung bifurcation effect, inertial force based cell separation, pinched flow fractionation, hydrodynamic filtration, or diffusion-based separation using H-filters as well as electrokinetic or acoustic strategies.91T ab le 3. 3.2.3. On-Chip Electrochemistry. Electrochemistry is a promising detection strategy combined with LOC systems as it offers high sensitivity, low costs, low power requirement, independency of optical pathways, and a distinctive compatibility with microfabrication and micromachining technologies.99 The WE is the heart of the electrochemical detection. It is the place where the detection reaction occurs. The WE has to be selected regarding the redox behavior of the target analyte and the background current over the region of interest. The most common WE materials in LOC devices are carbon, gold, and platinum. Different forms of carbon electrodes are integrated into LOC systems, e.g. carbon paste, carbon ink, or glassy carbon.100 In the following, the most successful strategies of how to integrate electrochemical detection with LOC are described. Some refer back to older publications so that a good overview of possible solutions can be provided. The most recent publications were selected as they portray the range of new strategies that help in overcoming the inherent challenges of electrode integration. Electrodes in microfluidic systems can be produced with thin-film or thick-film techniques, respectively. Thick-film technology, with screen printing as its most established technique, in general is significantly cheaper than thin-film technology of noble metals and is highly compatible with the fabrication of carbon electrodes. Screen printing of carbon electrodes can be performed on various substrates, e.g. alumina ceramic plate,101 PDMS,102 and thermoplastics,103−105 and can successfully be integrated into microfluidic systems. Also, the technique is popular to provide Ag/AgCl REs (Figure 5).106,107 In fact, for the integration of electrodes into paper-based LOC platforms, screen printing of the electrodes is the most common technique. Additionally, inkjet printing has been employed as an efficient technique to pattern electrodes on flexible substrates. For example, inkjet printing of silver electrodes on PDMS is reported by Wu et al.108 (Figure 6-1). Inkjet-printed gold electrodes on paper are reported as well.109 Common electrode materials for the WE and CE are carbon, copper, gold, or aluminum ink, while the RE is usually fabricated with Ag/AgCl inks.90 In 2009 Dungchai et al. demonstrated the electrochemical detection of glucose, lactate, and uric acid (UA) on a paper-based LOC system.110 Ko et al. reported an electrical paper device with inkjet-printed carbon nanotube electrodes (Figure 6-2).111
Thin-film technology requires sophisticated instruments to create an electrode film (tens to a few hundreds of nanometers film thickness), especially for metals such as gold and platinum on rigid substrates such as glass and silicon wafers. For example, Ginet et al. fabricated gold microwires on a glass wafer by thermal evaporation (Figure 7-1).112
Deposition of gold electrodes by sputtering is also widely used.114 In addition, Hilmi et al. reported electroless deposition of thin-film gold electrodes to a glass substrate, which can be simply and routinely performed in any wetchemistry laboratory.115 Thin-film fabrication based techniques typically require added adhesive layer, e.g. Ti and Cr, in order to support the bonding between metal film and substrates.112,113,115,116 Patterning electrodes can be performed using depositing thin film through a mask,117 using laser ablation, or using standard lithography followed by a lift-off process with higher resolution.118 Furthermore, electrodeposition performed on base conductive electrodes has been employed to form thin-film bismuth electrodes on patterned gold electrodes.119,120
The REs can be integrated using Ag/AgCl pastes,104 using screen printing,107,121 using an Ag/AgCl wire as RE,105 or using sputtered Ag REs.122 The integration of Ag/AgCl REs into microfluidic systems is often challenging. One major problem is the difficulty in transferring an internal electrolyte solution to miniaturized systems to construct the Ag/AgCl RE configuration similar to the stable macro RE. Thus, most miniaturized Ag/AgCl REs simply rely on “quasi-REs” or “pseudo-REs” where the Ag/AgCl is in direct contact with test solutions. Although the RE system has been successfully implemented to LOC-based voltammetric sensors, degradation of AgCl limits the longevity of pseudo-Ag/AgCl REs.123 Moreover, the unstable ionic strength restricts the application of pseudo-REs in potentiometric measurement. As a result, a variety of strategies are proposed to overcome those problems.124 A widely used strategy is the generation of salt bridges between the electrode and the channel.125−127 A similar approach without the need of a solid salt bridge is reported by Wongkaew et al. A Ag RE is implemented into a side channel, containing KCl solution, that is pushed
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.8b00172 Chem. Rev. 2019, 119, 120−194
127
uninterrupted into the main channel.128 The strategy is highly suitable for application in miniaturized potentiometric sensors in which a stable potential regardless of ionic strengths of test solutions is required. Alternatively, also pseudo-REs made of other metallic materials were integrated into microfluidic systems. For example, Odijk et al. used sputtered palladium as quasiRE,129 while Noh et al. used an RE of nanoporous platinum.130 Schumacher et al. reported the use of a sputtered iridium/ iridium oxide RE on a silicon wafer (Figure 7-2).113

sections.heading: 4. WHICH CHEMISTRIES DO NANOMATERIALS OFFER FOR ELECTROCHEMICAL SENSING?
sections.text: In this section, the focus will be on the intrinsic properties gained after synthesis or fabrication of the nanomaterials. Further characteristics gained through postmodification procedures will not be considered as those are not inherent to the nanomaterial and hence could be added to any other material as well.

sections.heading: 4.1. Nanomaterials Made of Metals and Metal Oxide
sections.text:
Metals and metal oxides are very-well-known catalysts driving many catalytic reactions. They are also widely used in electrochemical biosensors enabling nonenzymatic detection of metabolites such as sugars and reactive oxygen species, and enabling catalyst-enhanced signal amplification. Since the discovery of intrinsic enzyme-like activity of nanoparticles, e.g. gold nanoparticles (AuNPs)131 and Fe3O4,
132 many researchers focused on the development of nonenzymatic electrochemical sensing as can be seen from more than 800 articles during the past 10 years, when searching for “nonenzymatic electrochemical sensor” in the Web of Science. Pt, Pd, NiO, CuO, and other metals with various nanostructure forms, e.g. nanoparticles and nanowires, have been widely exploited for the development of the fourth generation of electrochemical glucose sensors as reviewed in refs 133−135 (Figure 8-1). Among other compounds, Ni and its composites have been the most promising candidates for glucose sensing. The catalytic activity results from the redox couple of Ni3+/ Ni2+ in alkaline media. The principle of electrocatalytic activity for glucose sensing relies on the formation of catalytic surfaces with Ni2+ using alkaline media (Ni(OH)2), followed by the oxidation of Ni2+ to Ni3+ at a given potential (Figure 8-2). The oxidation of glucose molecules to gluconolactone is realized by the +3 state in NiOOH, enabling the recycling of the +2 state in Ni(OH)2. Metal and metal oxide nanomaterials such as Fe3O4, TiO2, Au, Pt, and Pd have been widely used for electrochemical detection of H2O2, in which Fe3O4 dominates the research
field.137,138 Fe3O4 possesses peroxidase-like activity, similar to horseradish peroxidase (HRP) that can catalyze the electrochemical reaction as shown in Figure 9. This is of great significance in biosensor development as many oxidases
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.8b00172 Chem. Rev. 2019, 119, 120−194
128
produce H2O2a prime example being the glucose sensors that are based on monitoring hydrogen H2O2 production (Figure 8-1, first generation electrochemical glucose biosensor). In addition, Fe3O4 nanoparticles exhibit an intrinsic catalytic activity toward the electrochemical reduction of small dye molecules such as thionine (TH), which is a redox dye widely used for the generation of electrochemical signals.140
The catalytic activity of noble metal nanomaterials, in particular gold and silver, can also be exploited for signal generation or signal amplification strategies as the deposition of the metal is induced through reduction of metal ions in the
presence of reducing agent, e.g. hydroquinone. Detection of the deposited metals can be performed by either direct oxidation of the metallic form or acid dissolution prior to coupling with stripping analysis141 that dramatically decreases the limits of detection in comparison to the former technique.142,143 In more advanced applications the reducing agent is generated directly in the assay through associated enzymes and must not be added to the assay. Specifically, gold nanoclusters (AuNCs) were incorporated with alkaline phosphatase (ALP) to enhance the catalytic deposition of silver and hence result in ultrasensitive detection of nucleic acids and proteins.144,145 Here, ALP catalyzes the hydrolysis of
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.8b00172 Chem. Rev. 2019, 119, 120−194
129
phosphate groups from substrates such as ascorbic acid 2- phosphate or 3-indoxyl phosphate, generating the reducing agents that can promote silver reduction from silver nitrate.146
Furthermore, intrinsic surface properties of metal and metal oxide nanomaterials can directly promote their conjugation to receptor molecules. Owing to their inherent isoelectric point (IEP or pI), metal and metal oxide nanomaterials exhibit different surface charges that are largely influenced by the surrounding environment, in particular by the pH. Thus, immobilization of charged bioreceptors such as nucleic acids and proteins without further complicated modifications is possible.147−149 Additionally, noble metal nanomaterials, especially gold, are known for their strong bonds with sulfurcontaining molecules, which is probably the most used immobilization strategy for gold particles today.150,151 Further reading on metal oxide nanostructures with their use as immobilization surfaces for biosensors can be found in ref 152.

sections.heading: 4.2. Nanomaterials Based on Carbon and Nitrogen-Doped Carbon
sections.text:
Carbon nanomaterials, e.g. graphene, carbon nanotubes (CNTs), and carbon nanofibers (CNFs), have been extensively studied and applied in electrochemical sensors.153−156 Pristine graphene and CNTs have similar carbon structure arrangements in which the planar sheet of sp2-bonded carbon atoms are perfectly organized in a honeycomb lattice (Figure 10). The arrangement facilitates the delocalization of π electrons across the plane, which makes graphene and CNTs an excellent electrical conductor. In addition, a wide variety of aromatic group containing molecules can be noncovalently linked to the plane of pristine graphene or to the sidewalls of CNTs via strong π−π interactions. This interaction facilitates immensely the construction of electrochemical biosensors as BREs can easily be immobilized.157−160 In addition, it can assist in the preconcentration of analytes that contain aromatic groups, e.g. dopamine (DA), onto the traducers.158 However, this feature can also promote surface fouling, in particular with phenolic compounds which are ubiquitous especially in food and environmental samples161 and proteins.162
Carbon nanomaterials with oxygen-containing groups (also referred to as defects) such as reduced graphene oxide (rGO), graphene oxide (GO), and acid-treated CNTs (Figure 10) are less conductive than the pristine carbon counterparts as the electron delocalization is interrupted, forming sp3-bonded carbon atoms. Higher oxygen to carbon ratios of carbon nanomaterials result thus in lower electrical conductivity. However, the defects are very beneficial when applying these carbon nanomaterials in electrochemical biosensors. For example, carboxylic groups presented at the edges or basal plane of carbon nanomaterials can be covalently linked to primary amine-containing molecules or can be electrostatically adsorbed onto positively charged surfaces.163−165 In addition, the oxygen-containing groups can serve as anchoring sites for in situ deposition of a wide variety of metal nanoparticles,166 promoting the development of nonenzymatic electrochemical sensing. Furthermore, the negatively charged carbon nanomaterials can be very useful to repel the byproducts of phenolic compounds161 and to suppress thus interferences such as by ascorbic acid (AA).167,168
Doping with foreign atoms, e.g. boron (B), nitrogen (N), and phosphorus (P), can generate additional useful chemical reactivity and functionality to carbon nanomaterials171 of special interest to electrochemical sensing. In particular,
nitrogen is an interesting doping candidate because it possesses five valence electrons and is in size similar to carbon and hence can form strong valence bonds with carbon atoms (Figure 11- 1). Thus, the enhancement of conductivity could be expected due to the increased number of free charge carriers in the aromatic rings of sp2-carbon nanomaterials.172 In addition, nitrogen-doped carbon exhibits catalytic activity toward oxygen reduction reactions (ORRs) such as the oxidation of H2O2 and is hence similar to Pt-decorated CNTs,173 due to strong electronic affinity of nitrogen atoms and high positive charge density of the adjacent carbon atoms leading to favorable sites for oxygen adsorption and subsequent weakening of O−O bonding. In another work, nitrogen doping into graphene has shown to significantly contribute to the reduction of H2O2, as can be seen from the electrochemical signals depicted in Figure 11-2,3.174
Nitrogen-doped carbon nanomaterials have also been used for simultaneous detection of DA, AA, and UA.175−178 The nitrogen atoms in carbon nanomaterials can provide wellresolved oxidation peaks of those analytes, while the carbon nanomaterials and carbon electrode cannot (Figure 12). Zheng
et al. explained that the superior electrocatalytic activity may be attributed to the fact that nitrogen atoms in carbon nanomaterials can interact with DA, AA, and UA via hydrogen bonds, which subsequently activates the hydroxy and amine groups and accelerates the charge transfer kinetics of these molecules at the electrode interface.175 Various nitrogen contents were shown to affect the electrochemical signals for simultaneous detection of DA, AA, and UA.176
Furthermore, the substitution of carbon atom by nitrogen can modulate the electronic properties, leading to a metal− semiconductor transition.179 Therefore, nitrogen-doped carbon nanomaterials are promising to apply as a transducer in FET biosensing systems.180,181

sections.heading: 4.3. Nanomaterials Based on Conducting Polymers
sections.text:
CPs are an organic semiconductor consisting of conjugated chemical double bonds along the polymer chain. The electrical conduction can be obtained after doping by inducing the delocalization of electrons along the chain (Figure 13-1).
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.8b00172 Chem. Rev. 2019, 119, 120−194
130
Electrical conductivity of CPs can be tuned by the degree of doping and addition of electroactive species (Figure 13-2).
The doping process can be classified into two types, namely, redox doping and nonredox doping.183,184 The former process commonly applies to the case of PPy and PEDOT. Under ambient conditions, PPy’s and PEDOT’s backbones are nonconductive and prone to oxidation, bearing a positive charge every three to four monomer units. As a result, they can attract negatively charged dopants, which promote electrical conduction as well as balance the charges on the polymer backbones. On the contrary, there is no change of the number of electrons along the polymer backbone during the doping process for nonredox doping, but the energy levels are rearranged instead. The nonredox doping process applies to the generation of conductive PANI. In this case, nonconductive PANI is exposed to protonic acids, either inorganic acid (e.g., HCl) or organic (e.g., camphorsulfonic acid). The imine nitrogen atoms on the PANI backbone are protonated, in which the degree of protonation is dependent on its oxidation state and pH. Upon complete protonation of the
emeraldine base form (half-oxidized polymer) with aqueous HCl, for instance, an increase in conductivity about 10 orders of magnitude can be obtained through the formation of a delocalized polysemiquinone radical cation.184 Doping with organic acids is favorable for the development of electrochemical biosensors as the hydrophobic moiety of the acid dopant can stabilize the protonating form under physiological pH conditions. As the doping process is reversible and the dopant stability is highly dependent on the surrounding conditions, these polymers can be exploited as transducers and monitor electrical conductivity changes.185 For example, PANI has been widely applied for NH3 sensing by determining the change of resistivity as reviewed in ref 186. Furthermore, electrochemical detection techniques, e.g. potentiometry,187 conductometry, and amperometry,149 based on CPs have been used in chemical sensor/biosensor systems. Besides the merit of their sensing mechanism, the manipulation of dopant concentration and charge by the surrounding environment makes conductive polymers useful for sample preparation and immobilization. For example, negatively charged biomolecules such as nucleic acids can be electrostatically adsorbed on the positively charged conducting polymers, facilitating the filtration process188 or assisting the immobilization process.189 For sample preparation purpose, effective desorption of the adsorbed species is accomplished by simply changing the surrounding environment that promotes the opposite charge of the CPs.188
Finally, CPs also offer important functional groups, e.g. −CN, −NH−, or, most importantly, −SH, that facilitate the formation of CP−metal nanoparticle hybrids through selfassembly. Especially the high affinity between noble metal nanoparticles and CPs containing sulfur groups is interesting for the fabrication of sensing elements that enhance electrocatalytic activity and further serve as immobilization surfaces for BREs.190,191 Moreover, metal ions can be spontaneously or electrochemically reduced onto the CPs, forming metal nanoparticle decorated CPs.192,193

sections.heading: 5.1. Overview of Nanomaterials and Nanostructures Relevant to Electrochemical Sensing
sections.text:
Nanomaterials and nanostructures have attracted significant attention in electrochemical sensing for more than a decade. Unique physical and chemical properties make materials at the nanoscale excellent candidates to design and construct high performance electrochemical biosensors with a wide variety of functionality, not limited to being a superior transducer but also exploited for signal generation and enhancement (Figure 14). Their high surface-to-volume ratio is the major advantage of nanomaterials and nanostructures that can play an important role in maximizing analytical sensitivity. In addition, surface functionalities can be introduced either directly during modification and/or postmodification similar to bulk materials (see also section 2.5).194 Nowadays, advanced synthesis/ fabrication of nanoscale objects enables also controlled design of materials with different shapes, sizes, arrangements, and compositions.195 Consequently, the use of nanomaterials and nanostructures in electrochemical biosensors has increased dramatically. The following section will focus on their classifications and syntheses, and discuss intrinsic benefits for electrochemical biosensors that are enabled by their physical and inherent chemical properties, summarized in Table 5. Our
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.8b00172 Chem. Rev. 2019, 119, 120−194
131
collection herein has demonstrated that the benefits of using nanomaterials and nanostructures can be derived from two facts, i.e., (1) reducing the entire size of the structure into nanoscales, and (2) applying or integrating the nanosized materials/structures to the macroscopic devices, e.g. electrodes. It should also be noted that the term “nanomaterials” and “nanostructures” in this review refer mainly to the engineered materials that are intentionally constructed or synthesized for specific purposes. Thus, naturally or incidentally occurring nanosized objects, e.g. the electrochemical double layer (a few nanometers thickness) or mere biological molecules, are excluded. 5.1.1. Zero-Dimensional (0-D) Nanomaterials. Any object with all dimensions (x, y, and z) in the nanoscale is classified as zero-dimensional material (0-D).196 Zero-dimensional is recognized as the most basic and symmetric shape which can be presented as spherical, cubic, or triangular forms.197 All dimensions in nanoscale of 0-D nanomaterials lead to confined electrons in 3-D space without electron delocalization, allowing their free movement.196 Nanoparticles with various types and compositions are the most common representation of 0-D nanomaterials. They have been employed extensively in electrochemical sensing as signal tracers, catalysts, labeling carriers, and separators.
Noble-metal nanoparticles have long been used in electrochemical biosensors due to excellent electrical conductivity, ease of surface modification and synthesis, and good biocompatibility (for platinum and gold).198 Synthesis of metallic nanoparticles through a bottom-up approach is the most common means to achieve isolable particles in colloidal form with the assistance of a protecting shell either from inherent charges or from organic surfactant such as cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB).199 Chemical reduction of metal precursors as shown in Figure 15, e.g. HAuCl4, AgNO3, H2PtCl6, or PdCl2, in the presence of stabilizing agents leads to the formation of 10−50 nm particles with surface moieties determined by the capping agents used. Sizes and shape of the nanoparticles can be tuned through manipulation of reaction conditions such as precursor concentration, ratio of chemical compositions, surface modifier, and temperature.200,201 Monodisperse nanoparticles (size distribution less than 5%) and high colloidal stability in biological buffers are the major determinant of success and ultimately lead to and support the sensitivity and reproducibility of electrochemical sensors. Nanoparticles between 10 and 50 nm have been the most widely used in electrochemical sensing due to higher colloidal stability and higher surfacearea-to-volume ratio when compared to larger particles.151,202,203
Synthesis of other reactive metal nanoparticles such as those made of Ni, Cu, and Cr in aqueous solution are commonly carried out in the same way, but the reaction conditions have to be performed strictly in inert atmosphere to prevent oxidation.205,206 Semiconducting nanoparticles are made from a variety of different compounds which are known as II−VI, III−V, or IV−VI semiconductor nanocrystals according to the groups in the periodic table. CdS, CdTe, CdSe, ZnS, and PbS are most commonly used semiconducting nanoparticles in electrochemical biosensors, especially as electrochemical labels for single analyte207 or simultaneous detection of multianalytes.208,209
Besides colloidal solution based synthesis using capping agents, electrochemical reduction of metal salt onto electrochemical transducers is considered a simple technique that allows easy control of the nucleation and growth of metal nanoparticles resulting also in strong adhesion. Size, deposition potential, substrate, and deposition time are major factors that govern the size and distribution of as-grown metal nanoparticles.210 The technique has been widely used to enhance surface area and the reactivity of electrodes, in particular, enabling desired catalytic effects toward target analytes which is of interest for the development of electrochemical nonenzymatic sensors.151,211,212
Magnetic nanoparticles (MNPs) are of one of the major 0-D nanomaterials that have been extensively used in electrochemical biosensors, in particular for efficient separation upon applying an external magnetic field. In addition, MNPs can serve as nanocarriers for electroactive molecules.213,214 Overcoming diffusion limitations during the binding reaction, enabling simple wash strategies, and the processing of larger sample volumes are the overarching benefits that are also harnessed in electrochemical biosensors. Magnetite (Fe3O4) exhibits ferromagnetic or superparamagnetic behavior depending on the particle size.215 Chemical coprecipitation techniques of iron salts is known as the simplest and most effective method for mass production of MNPs.215,216 The Fe3O4 nanoparticles are however prone to oxidation generating a

Magnetic particles with dimensions in the micrometer range exhibit higher magnetic strength than nanosized particles, are commercially available from various sources, and are widely employed for efficient separation prior to electrochemical biosensing, yet nanosized particles are more favorable and practical to apply into miniaturized systems due to exhibiting higher surface-area-to-volume ratios, greater stability in suspension, and less susceptibility to particle clustering by applying a magnetic field.217
5.1.2. One-Dimensional (1-D) Nanomaterials. Objects with two dimensions that are in the nanoscale but one dimension outside of this nanoscale are referred to as 1-D nanomaterials. Electron confinement occurs in 2-D but electron delocalization takes place only along the long axis, which makes 1-D nanostructures very sensitive to small variations at the surface. This can be exploited in sensors for the highly sensitive detection of analyte, for example upon analyte binding or chemical reactions taking place on said surface. With their unique electronic properties together with high surface-area-to-volume ratio, they have been widely used as a detector in electrochemical sensors especially for label-free based detection as the conductance is greatly affected by small surface perturbations. In addition, some 1-D nanomaterials with shorter macroscale length such as nanotubes and nanorods have been used as nanocarriers. 5.1.2.1. Nanotubes. Nanotubes, especially CNTs, were intensively studied also for use in electrochemical sensors over the past two decades as shown in a number of review articles.167,218−221 CNTs, first discovered by Ijima,222 are made of graphene (a two-dimensional honeycomb structure with sp2hybridized carbon) sheet/sheets rolled up to seamless hollow tube/tubes (Figure 16). Depending on the number of
graphene sheets, CNTs are classified as single-walled carbon nanotubes (SWNTs) (with typical diameters between 0.4 and 2 nm) and multiwalled carbon nanotubes (MWNTs) (diameters between 2 and 100 nm with a distance between the layers of ∼0.34 nm).223 The lengths of CNTs can range from tens of nanometers to several micrometers. Growing CNTs can be achieved through the following main techniques: electric arc discharge, laser ablation, high-pressure carbon monoxide method, and catalyzed chemical vapor deposition (cCVD). The first three routes require a cleanup procedure after growth due to large amounts of byproducts. cCVD is therefore the most popular method to produce high-quality CNTs with high yield.224 This method relies on the decomposition of a hydrocarbon gas over a transition metal catalyst such as Ni and initiation of CNT synthesis by some of the resulting carbon atoms. The cCVD growth mechanism generally involves the dissociation of hydrocarbon molecules and saturation of carbon atoms on the catalyst metal nanoparticles. The precipitation of carbon from the saturated metal particles leads to the formation of CNTs. Catalyst particle diameters and shape play an important role in defining the synthesized carbon nanostructure.225 SWNTs and MWNTs form particles of the order of 1 nm diameter and 10−50 nm, respectively, in which the number of layers increases with the particle diameter.226 The ends of nanotubes can be opened or closed. The open ends of CNTs have been likened to edge planes of HOPG which should have excellent electron transport properties, whereas the walls are suggested to have properties similar to those of basal planes of HOPG electrodes which exhibit slower electron transfer kinetics (Figure 16).224
During the 2000s CNTs were extensively studied and applied in electrochemical biosensors. For example, Gong et al. (Figure 17) studied the roles of CNT tips, sidewalls, and oxygen-containing surface groups in electrochemical sensing of common analytes such as K3[Fe(CN)6], NADH, AA, cysteine, and H2O2.
227 Their results clearly indicated that nanotube tip and/or oxygen-containing surface groups do not necessarily facilitate electroactive properties of CNTs and that instead it depends on reaction mechanisms of the analytes. The orientation of CNTs also plays a critical role in electrochemical performance as demonstrated by Liu et al. Vertically aligned short CNTs on a flat gold electrode provided better electrochemical performance for K3[Fe(CN)6] than the CNTs that lie down on the electrode due to high accessibility of the ends of the tubes to the sample.228 In order to efficiently fabricate CNT electrode arrays, in which the sidewalls are embedded inside the insulator and only the CNT tips are exposed to analyte solution, optimal density of CNT electrodes is required to avoid significant overlap of the diffusion layers from each CNT electrode, thus promoting efficient mass transport through nonplanar radial diffusion.229 These studies enable the efficient and targeted design and development of CNT-based electrochemical sensors and biosensors. Apart from using CNTs as electrodes, they have been extensively used as modifying agents in order to promote electron transfer between biorecognition molecules and the electrodes. As electrons of SWNTs have very high mobility and all atoms are located at the surface, they are the ideal material to serve as nanoelectric connectors. Many reports use this concept, i.e. SWNTs as a molecular wire enabling electrical communication between electrodes and redox proteins (often their prosthetic group) linked to the ends of the SWNTs,230,231
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.8b00172 Chem. Rev. 2019, 119, 120−194
135
resulting in an elegant, reagentless biosensor design. As the rate of electron transport is governed by the length of the nanotubes, the nanoparticle size and dimension assist in optimizing the electrochemical biosensor performance.231
The immobilization of CNTs is typically obtained through covalent linkage or hydrophobic interactions. Specifically, short CNT fragments containing carboxyl groups are useful as carriers for enzymes232 or as redox molecule tags,233 and a high degree of carboxylation facilitates the ability of CNTs to covalently conjugate to enzymes and biorecognition probes, e.g., antibody and DNA.234 Alternatively, hydrophobic parts of proteins and electroactive molecules can simply adsorb onto the hydrophobic sidewalls of CNTs.233,235 Due to their high
loading capacity, for example 9600 enzyme molecules per CNT, CNT tag can dramatically improve detection sensitivity, and was demonstrated to be better than using PS beads as carrier material.234
Nowadays, CNTs have successfully proven their capability in enhancing electrochemical biosensor performance, especially in combination with other materials forming CNT composites.167 However, the difficulty in handling CNTs in a controllable manner caused by poor dispersibility in aqueous solutions remains a major issue that suggests efficient prefunctionalization is required to enable reliable and reproducible construction of transducers and labels.236 In addition to aggregation issues, large sheet resistance of CNT film caused by disconnection between each CNT during stretching limits their use in the development of stretchable sensors. Jin et al. recently addressed the problem by coating and binding CNTs with a conductive polymer, PEDOT, which is able to reduce contact resistance and protects the CNT junctions from disconnection. Thus, excellent electrochemical performance is retained during electrode deformation.237
5.1.2.2. Nanorods. Nanorods describe rod-like-shaped nanoparticles and a shorter form of nanowires that have typically diameters in the range of a few tens of nanometers while their lengths can be expanded from several tens to a hundred nanometers.238 Synthesis of nanorods can be achieved through a variety of techniques such as template-assisted electrochemical synthesis239,240 with seed-mediated synthesis being the most popular (Figure 18). Combinations of ligands act as shape control agents and bond to different facets of the nanorod with different strengths. This allows different faces of the nanorod to grow at different rates, producing an elongated object. Nanorods can be synthesized from metals or semiconducting materials with controllable aspect ratios in solution (Figure 18-1)241,242 or onto surfaces (Figure 18-2).243
Gold nanorods (AuNRs) have been widely used in electrochemical biosensors244 as label carriers245 and electrode modifiers for sensitivity enhancement or serving as nonenzymatic catalysts.246 AuNRs with different aspect ratios (2.20, 2.80, and 2.77) were self-assembled onto a thiolated gold electrode in order to study their electrochemical performance related to nanorod size.247 It was found that the nanorods with the smallest aspect ratio in this study
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.8b00172 Chem. Rev. 2019, 119, 120−194
136
presented their ends bonding to the electrodes while the others showed a side surface attachment. Furthermore, the electrodes modified with vertically aligned nanorods exhibited efficient electron transfers leading to the highest electrochemical responses, which is likely due to most of the nanorod surfaces being exposed to the test solution. In addition, AuNRs with a smaller aspect ratio (1.6) resulted in greater uniform coating on the surface of Fe3O4 nanoparticles than the long nanorods (aspect ratio of 7.5) as reported recently by Munshi et al.248 In fact, GCEs modified with the shorter AuNR-Fe3O4 hybrid provided a 5-time higher signal current for H2O2 detection than the hybrid with longer nanorods. Comparing AuNRs and AuNPs, Prasad et al. showed that AuNRs are a better substrate for molecular imprinting and thus enhance electrochemical sensitivity for the determination of an anticancer drug (cytosine arabinoside, Ara-C).249 In this comparative study, a pencil graphite electrode (PGE) was first modified with either AuNRs or AuNPs before coating with the prepolymer solution (template Ara-C) mixed with monomer and cross-linking agent). Subsequent extraction of the template provides specific recognition sites for binding to Ara-C. The different curvatures and morphologies of nanoparticles and nanorods greatly influenced the electrochemical performance of the imprinted electrode. Specifically, nanorods as modifier gave a ca. 4 times lower limit of detection, an order of magnitude faster electrode kinetics, and higher diffusivity. The authors suggested that the nanorod-decorated PGE may offer better electronic continuity as they have a smaller number of interfacial boundaries than the spherical nanoparticles.
5.1.2.3. Nanowires. Nanowires typically have diameters similar to nanotubes but have significantly greater length. In fact, CNTs with a length from submicrometers to 10 μm are occasionally considered as nanowires in some reports.250,251
The fabrication of nanowires such as CNTs and silicon nanowires is rather complicated and requires harsh conditions so that biofunctionalizations are mostly restricted to take place postsynthesis. CPs are an interesting alternative choice owing to their low cost and simple synthesis with less complicated instruments and conditions. The conductivity of these polymers can be modulated over a wide range through simple doping/dedoping chemistries. Moreover, desirable functionalization can be carried out flexibly before, during, or after synthesis. Therefore, CPs are becoming a popular material choice for biofunctionalized nanowire transducers for biosensing applications.252−256 Metallic nanowires with excellent electrical conductivity are of interest for nanoelectrodes in voltammetric biosensors. In general, nanoscale electrodes can promote radial diffusion and reduce the area of double-layer capacitances. Consequently, efficient mass transport and lower charging current will maximize signal-to-noise ratios (S/N). A single gold nanowire with diameter and length of 100 nm and 40 μm, respectively, was employed for electrochemical biosensing of glucose realized by steady-state voltammetric measurements.257 The device enabled high sensitivity and low limits of detection of glucose (3 μM, S/N = 3). In addition, this research group also reported that the as-prepared gold nanowire had very low capacitance which is about 3 orders of magnitude lower than that of ultramicroelectrodes.258

137
5.1.2.4. Nanofibers. Nanofibers typically have diameters ranging from a few to hundreds of nanometers with varying lengths depending on the production process.259 Figure 19 illustrates various strategies for nanofiber production made from synthetic polymers or biopolymers (Figure 19-1−6), and carbon (Figure 19-7). Continuous nanofibers with lengths up to several meters can be realized through the electrospinning process, so that nanofibers easily bridge into 3-D structures, which will be further discussed in section 5.1.4. Nanofibers are generally categorized into 1-D nanomaterial. However, their applications toward electrochemical biosensing realized by isolated single fibers or a few nanofibers are seldom reported.260 This is probably due to the challenge of device integration and mechanical stability in solution. However, there have been reports on using single nanofibers for gas sensing based on the resistance change of CPs, which demonstrates their similarity to nanowires used in sensors.261−263
Owing to their superior electrical conductivity, CNFs have attracted attention as electrochemical transducers similar to nanofibers made from CPs. CNFs should not be confused with CNTs, as CNFs have cylindrical nanostructures with graphene layers arranged in various forms as illustrated in Figure 20-1. Even though CNTs have higher electrical conductivity than CNFs,265 the arrangement of graphene sheets in CNFs offers remarkable benefits that make CNFs more attractive than CNTs in the development of electrochemical biosensors.266 First, the stacking of graphene sheets with various shapes generates more edge sites (electrochemically active parts; see also Figure 22) exposed on the exterior of CNFs, facilitating better electron transfer of electroactive analytes than CNTs.267 In addition, compared with CNTs, the entire surface area of CNFs can be activated without damaging the structural integrity of their backbones. Thus, CNFs are an excellent candidate to serve as immobilization matrixes for bioreceptors
while still preserving the highly efficient electron transfer along the CNF structure (Figure 20-2).268
5.1.3. Two-Dimensional (2-D) Nanomaterials. In 2-D nanomaterials, two of the dimensions are not confined to the nanoscale. Two-dimensional nanomaterials exhibit typically plate-like shapes. Two-dimensional nanomaterials include nanofilms, nanolayers, and nanocoatings. The conduction of electrons in 2-D nanomaterials will be confined across the thickness but delocalized in the plane of the sheet. Since Novoselov et al. demonstrated the ability to mechanically cleave graphitic sheets into a few atomic layers and even single layers, the ability to integrate them into electronic devices, and their remarkable electrical properties,270 2-D nanomaterials have gained enormous interest in a wide range of applications including electrochemical biosensors.271
5.1.3.1. Graphene. Graphene is a single layer of sp2hybridized carbon that is organized in a honeycomb lattice. In theory the thickness of a single layer graphene is ∼0.345 nm,272 but measured values have been reported in a wide range between 0.4 and 1.7 nm270,273 and their size can range from a few to several square micrometers. Both top-down and bottom-up approaches are popular for the synthesis of graphene. The idea of the former technique relies mainly on separating graphene layers from bulky graphite by breaking the weak van der Waals interactions between adjacent layers, which is also the same procedure used for other graphene-like layered compounds. Depending on how graphene layers are cleaved, the methods can be classified into mechanical, liquid, and chemical oxidation exfoliation. The first two methods typically maintain intrinsic properties of graphene and produce few defects, making the resulting graphene highly suitable for integrating into electronic devices. However, the poor production yield, requirement of surface support, and uncontrollable thickness are the major obstacles for general uses in electrochemical biosensors. Thus, chemical oxidation
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.8b00172 Chem. Rev. 2019, 119, 120−194
138
exfoliation is the most widely used technique for graphene preparation in biosensor applications, in particular following Hummers’ method.274 In this technique, graphite powder is oxidized in a mixture of sulfuric acid, sodium nitrate, and potassium permanganate to produce graphite oxide and later generate a single layer or a few layers of GO which can be dispersed very well in aqueous solution. GO sheets are rich in oxygen-containing groups, i.e. hydroxyl, epoxide on the basal planes, and carbonyl and carboxyl groups at the sheet edges. The groups were found to play an important role in repelling negatively charged interferences such as AA, especially in DA detection.168 In addition, they also serve as nucleation sites for the growth of noble metal nanoparticles.275,276
Removal of the oxygen functional groups of GO via reduction processes can be performed through a variety of strategies, e.g. chemical, electrochemical, or thermal reduction. The quality of each of these reduced GO (rGO) differs significantly as reviewed by Pei and Cheng277 and deserves more attention for electrochemical biosensor development. Wang et al. found that rGO by electrochemical technique exhibited better electroactivity than rGO obtained from chemical reduction as indicated by cyclic voltammograms of K3Fe(CN)6, NADH, and AA.
278 It is assumed that the electrochemical reduction generates graphene with defects which in turn become active sites for electrochemical reactions and functional groups for further biomolecule conjugations. A comparative study on the effect of various rGO prepared from different reduction methods showed that thermally reduced GO provided the most sensitive and selective response for UA determination compared to chemically and electrochemically reduced GO (approximately 4 times higher sensitivity and 2 times smaller half peak width).279 The result is consistent with the electrical conductivities reported by Shang et al. where the electrical conductivity of thermally reduced GO was about 2 times greater than that of the other two techniques.280 It is worth mentioning that reduced GO from different techniques provide each a distinct morphology and structure; i.e., randomly aggregated and crumpled sheets, stacked-film structure, and wrinkled sheets with a “fluffy” appearance (Figure 21) were obtained from chemical, electrochemical, and thermal reduction, respectively. The wrinkled sheets seem to play a significant role in providing a greater number of edges (active sites) which results in a better electrochemical sensitivity. CVD is a well-known bottom-up approach for graphene synthesis with high quality, controllable size and thickness. The technique requires a flat catalytic substrate, e.g. Cu foil or Ni foil, for synthesizing CVD graphene. The precursors react and/ or decompose on the substrate surface, forming a single layer or a few layers of graphene. In addition, a large area (square centimeter range) of a thin film containing single-to-few layers of graphene can be generated with low production cost and scalable capability.281 However, the required high temperature, inert gas, restricted substrate choices, and consequently complicated transfer processes render CVD graphene less applicable for biosensor development.271 In addition, Ambrosi and Pumera demonstrated that a common transfer process of CVD graphene by oxidant-etchant solutions introduces significant metallic impurities derived from iron-based-etching solution, e.g. FeCl3 and Fe(NO3)3 and dissolved metallic substrate (e.g., Ni or Cu), which in turn dramatically affects the electrochemical behavior of an electrode modified with transferred CVD graphene.282 Therefore, careful character-
ization should be conducted prior to using the transferred CVD graphene to alleviate misinterpretation of the electroanalytical performance. It may be noted that individual graphene layers are difficult to obtain as they tend to restack, forming multilayered graphene after synthesis. In fact, most bulk scale preparation techniques produce 99% multilayered structures and 1% monolayered graphene.283 Therefore, when graphene is used for electrode modifications in order to enhance detection sensitivity, in most cases, a multilayer structure is applied. In 2010, Goh and Pumera demonstrated that the number of layers did not influence voltammetric behaviors of DA detection whether the electrodes were modified with single-layer, few-layer (three or four layers), or multilayered (several hundreds of sheets) graphene sheets.284 However, interestingly, the same authors later reported that the number of graphene layers affect the sensitivity of guanine and adenine oxidation.285 In this study, they found that graphene with a few layers exhibited a greater sensitivity than double layer and multilayer graphenes. The authors suggested that the random assembly of a few layers of graphene on the GCE provides a higher number of electroactive edges exposed to the solution than a doubled layer graphene, where the two layers tend to assemble in plane in which the edges are covered by an additional layer of double layered graphene. The proposed explanation is well-consistent with ref 286, where the authors found no intrinsic advantage over GCEs when graphene was formed as a monolayer. Instead, introduction of electrode porosity through modification with multilayer porous graphene resulted in strong electrocatalytic effects and improved electrode selectivity toward DA detection even in the presence of AA and UA. By numerical simulations the authors explained that the porosity induced electrode selectivity by the dominance of pore depletion over diffusion-limited currents (see also section 5.1.4.1 and Figure 58 for more detail). Comparing CNTs and graphene in terms of production, the synthesis of graphene is considerably cheaper and more accessible in any laboratory. In addition, the growth of CNTs commonly requires metal nanoparticles as a catalyst which is typically embedded inside the CNT whereas production of graphene, in particular by a top-down approach, does not.
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.8b00172 Chem. Rev. 2019, 119, 120−194
139
Thus, using graphene prepared by a top-down-based technique in electrochemical sensing can alleviate misinterpretation when detecting analytes that can be catalyzed by metals, such as H2O2 (as discussed above, bottom-up graphene synthesis through CVD can encounter the same metal impurity challenges). Graphene also offers better analytical performance than CNTs because graphene sheets have a larger number of edges, where the active sites are located, and thus enables a faster heterogeneous electron transfer than CNTs (Figure
22).287 Further comparisons of electrochemical sensing properties for CNTs and graphene are given in many excellent review articles.288,289
5.1.3.2. Graphene-like 2-D Nanomaterials. Graphene-like 2-D nanomaterials have been widely investigated for electrochemical sensing due to their similar structural properties to graphene and the tunable band gap capability that is not present in graphene. The band gap is of interest as it allows electrical conduction through a material to be switchable (on
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.8b00172 Chem. Rev. 2019, 119, 120−194
140
and off), facilitating the building of FET-based electrochemical biosensors. The widely used graphene-like 2-D nanomaterials include transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDs),291,292 hexagonal boron nitride (h-BN) nanosheets, and graphite carbon nitride (g-C3N4) nanosheets. Their structures are illustrated in Figure 23. The current synthesis methods for graphene-like 2-D nanomaterials are similar to those for graphene, and their details can be found in refs 293 and 294. TMDs are composed of transition metals, e.g. molybdenum, tungsten, or niobium, linked with chalcogens, e.g. sulfur or selenium. Unlike graphene, a layer of transition metal atoms is sandwiched between two layers of chalcogen atoms with covalent bonds. The neighboring three-layer sheets are held together through weak van der Waals bonds, permitting cleavable sheets during exfoliations. Depending on their compositions and crystalline structure, the electronic properties of TMDs can be tuned as semiconductors, true metals, and superconductors.296 MoS2 is the most studied TMD and has been applied as a transducer in electrochemical biosensors. For example, it was employed to construct a FET biosensor.297 The authors demonstrated that the sensitivity of protein detection using MoS2 was 74-fold higher than using multilayer graphene (7 nm thickness). This is attributed to the presence of a band gap in MoS2 (1.8 eV for a monolayer to 1.2 eV for bulk) which enables a greater modulation of current in semiconducting channels of the FET system upon applying a gate voltage (Figure 24-1,2). On the contrary, the absence of a band gap in graphene leads to an increased leakage current as not only electrons can flow above the top of the barrier, but electrons with lower energies can also tunnel through the barrier (Figure 24-3). One-dimensional nanostructures such as CNT and silicon nanowires have been debated23,298 for FET-based biosensing due to their size compatibility and ability to provide high sensitivity; the issues on transducer and device fabrication and large-scale integration ability also limit their practical utility. On the other hand, 2-D nanomaterials with semiconducting properties and excellent electrostatic gating effects like MoS2 have thus become more attractive as the mass production cost can be lower. In addition, using a planar platform for the construction of FET system makes the patternability and integration ability easier than 1-D nanomaterials.297
Furthermore, recent studies demonstrated that MoS2 nanoflakes can serve as electroactive labels in which their inherent oxidation peak was exploited as the analytical signal.299 In this work, immobilized ssDNA probes were effectively bound to MoS2 nanoflakes via van der Waals forces between the nucleobases and the basal plane of MoS2 nanoflakes. The presence of complementary target DNA resulted in buried nucleobases, thus lowering the oxidative signal from MoS2 nanoflakes. This enabled a novel strategy for the voltammetric detection of DNA hybridization based MoS2 nanoflakes. BN nanosheets consist of alternating boron and nitrogen atoms in a honeycomb lattice structure with a wide band gap (5.2 eV); thus BN nanosheet is almost an insulator.300 Even though BN nanosheets seem to be a favorable candidate, there have been only a few investigations that attempted to demonstrate their benefits in electrochemical sensing.301−305 BN nanosheets are hydrophobic, so they have to be modified with a stabilizer such as diallyldimethylammonium chloride or chitosan to increase their stability and solubility in aqueous solution before electrodes can be modified and bioreceptors
can be immobilized. In electrochemical biosensor applications, BN nanosheets and their composites have been employed as matrixes to enhance the surface area of immobilized biological probes302,303 and to carry electrochemical catalysts such as AuNPs306 for electrochemical biosensor applications.
