Recently, Khan and co-workers explored a new functionality of 2Dhexagonal BN as an electrochemical catalyst for DA sensing.304 Here, a graphitic screen-printed electrode modified with the hBN sheets was able to resolve the oxidation peaks of DA and two common interferents, AA and UA, which could not be obtained with the unmodified electrode. g-C3N4 nanosheets are a polymeric graphitic carbon nitride made of C, N, and H atoms connected via tris-triazine-based patterns. They have a mild band gap energy (2.7 eV);307 thus g-C3N4 is an organic semiconductor. In general, nitrogendoped graphene has been of great interest in electrochemical sensing as the strong electron donor nature of nitrogen, which is absent in graphene, can affect the electronic structure and results in different mechanisms of activity enhancement. In addition, doping graphene with nitrogen atoms leads to the disruption of the basal surface and increased edge plane-like sites (i.e., electrochemically active part). As demonstrated by Wang et al., GCEs modified with nitrogen-doped graphene showed greater sensitivity for H2O2 detection than those modified with graphene.174 Furthermore, g-C3N4 nanosheets possess interesting catalytic activities, e.g. they function as peroxidase,308 which makes them attractive for developing electrochemical biosensors based nonenzymatic detection, for instance, for the detection of H2O2, nitrobenzene, NADH, 309 and glucose.310 However, they have very poor conductivity in electrochemical sensing applications; therefore, g-C3N4 nanosheets are often combined with materials that have greater conductivity such as graphene311 or CPs312 to enable efficient electron transfer. In addition to their catalytic property, g-C3N4 ultrathin sheets demonstrate strong affinity toward Hg2+ realized by intrinsic −NH and −NH2 groups of the gC3N4.
313 This in turn enables highly sensitive and selective analysis of mercury using anodic stripping analysis, which cannot be done using bulk g-C3N4.
5.1.4. Three-Dimensional (3-D) Nanomaterials. Threedimensional nanomaterials describe materials that are not confined to the nanoscale in any dimension; all three arbitrary dimensions are above 100 nm. They are still classified as nanomaterials because they possess a nanocrystalline structure or involve the presence of features at the nanoscale. In terms of nanocrystalline structure, bulk nanomaterials can be composed of multiple arrangements of nanosized crystals, most typically in different orientations. With respect to the presence of features at the nanoscale, 3-D nanomaterials can contain dispersions of nanoparticles, bundles of nanowires, and nanotubes as well as multinanolayers.196
Three-dimensional nanomaterials have been widely used in electrochemical biosensors as electrodes, surfaces for bioreceptor immobilization, and scaffolds for cells. In addition, they are used as separators in sample preparation. In this section, 3-D nanomaterials including metallic nanoporous structures (section 5.1.4.1), graphene foam (section 5.1.4.2.1), nanofibers (section 5.1.4.2.2), and nanocontainers (section 5.1.4.3) including nanoporous microspheres and nanovesicles will be discussed.
5.1.4.1. Metallic Nanoporous Materials. Metallic nanoporous films are of interest as electrode materials in electrochemical biosensors since they offer obvious large
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.8b00172 Chem. Rev. 2019, 119, 120−194
141
surface area advantages. Factors that must be considered though include the type of analyte, the nature of their electrochemical reactions (diffusion or kinetic control), the detection frequency or scan rate, and ultimately also the accessible space inside the pores. Li et al. first described the fabrication of WEs made of gold thin film containing nanopores and their use in electrochemical biosensors.314 The as-prepared nanoporous electrodes possess uniform pore structure, large electroactive surface area, and high electrical conductivity. Apart from 40 times more active area than a flat layer, the authors found that nanoporous structured electrodes enabled greater adhesion stability of electrodeposited mediators (Prussian Blue) due to their entrapment capability in contrast to flat surfaces. In addition, enzymes could efficiently be retained on the nanostructure electrodes; especially no leakage of entrapped enzymes was found when the electrodes were used inside microfluidic systems with a 30 μL s−1 (3 mm s−1) flow rate. The nature of the redox reaction determines whether nanoporous electrode structures are beneficial. For example, redox markers such as potassium ferrocyanide and ruthenium hexamine chloride exhibit diffusion-controlled behavior due to fast electron transfer rate constants. When the reaction of these redox markers occurs at the nanoporous electrode, an increased surface area bears no advantage as the molecules do not have enough time to access the inside of the nanocavities and tend to react at the rim of the pores (Figure 25-1c). On the other hand, redox molecules with slow reaction rates and a non-diffusion-controlled system, such as glucose and methylene blue, can realize the benefit of enhanced surface areas as they can enter deeper inside the nanocavities prior to the electrochemical reaction taking place (Figure 25-1d). These observations are also supported by Park and colleagues’ investigation. They studied the relationship between the ratio of the real surface area to apparent area, termed roughness factor (Rf), and the participated electrochemical reactions for analytes with fast and slow electrokinetic processes as displayed in Figure 25-2. Thin-film nanoporous
electrodes (low Rf as indicated by Figure 25-2a,b) promote the participation of electrochemical reactions of O2 and H2O2, while in the thick-film electrodes (high Rf as indicated by
Figure 25-2c,d) the reaction takes place only on the top surfaces. On the other hand, the reaction of glucose, with slow reaction kinetics, can occur better when the thickness of the nanoporous electrode increases (Figure 25-2f−h). Furthermore, this behavior enabled the selectivity for nonenzymatic detection of glucose realized by nanostructure electrodes as reported by Park et al.317
In 2015, Daggumati et al. comprehensively studied the effect of nanoporous gold (np-Au) morphology on the performance of DNA sensors using methylene blue as a redox marker.318 That study has shown that the annealed nanoporous gold electrodes which are obtained after thermal treatment of the nanoporous gold film (Figure 26-1) enhance the accessibility of DNA probes, DNA targets, and methylene blue, resulting in higher immobilized probe density, greater hybridization events, and ultimately better sensing performance over unannealed and flat gold electrodes (Figure 26-2). This work also demonstrated the dependence of optimal electrochemical measurement based on SWV frequency on electrode morphology. The signal amplitude increased with the increase of frequency until 60 Hz and then became saturated for the flat Au surface. On the other hand, the signal amplitudes from nanoporous gold for both unannealed nanoporous-Au film and annealed nanoporous-Au film increased at low SWV frequencies until reaching critical values, which are 18 and 30 Hz, respectively. Afterward, the signals dropped at higher frequencies. This was explained by the fact that the ionic species of the electrolyte have insufficient time to fully permeate the nanoporous electrode at high frequencies, limiting the electrochemically active surface area. Therefore, optimal scan rates and frequencies must be taken into account to realize the full potential of nanoporous electrodes.318
Recently, the same research group has extended their study on the relationship between pore radii and electrochemical sensing performance of DNA as well as antibiofouling
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.8b00172 Chem. Rev. 2019, 119, 120−194
142
capability.319 The pore radii were tuned by in situ electrochemical coarsening methods realized by CV in which a higher number of CV cycles leads to larger pore sizes (Figure 27). The study demonstrated that an optimum pore radius is required in order to realize high surface areas of the nanostructure and effective biofouling resilience. The nanoporous electrode with too-large pore radii resulted in the penetration of interfering proteins into the pores, potentially blocking access of target DNA, while too-small pore radii lowered the hybridization event (Figure 27). In addition to a voltammetric-based electrochemical sensor, nanoporous electrodes were described to improve the sensitivity and selectivity of conductometric detection of analyte ions at high concentration.320 The available large surface area of 3-D nanoporous Pt significantly suppressed the impedance at the electrode−solution interface, leading to a larger contribution of the solution resistance to the total impedance. It was suggested that the selectivity of analyte ions at low frequency is attributed to the pore effect. In another work, nanoporous electrodes with uniform pore size and geometry were shown to exhibit better performance.321
5.1.4.2. Nonmetallic Nanoporous Materials. 5.1.4.2.1. Graphene Foam. Three-dimensional graphene-based materials
(also termed “graphene foam”), especially freestanding porous graphene with controllable pore size and void space, have been studied as electrode material.322 Here, the advantages inherent to 2-D graphene are combined with the general benefits of porous structures. Thus, the interconnected porous network, high electrical conductivity, and accessible large active surface area promote high efficient current/signal collection from the entire electrode surface and accommodates more bioreceptors, especially in comparison to 2-D electrodes. In addition, graphene as a 3-D structure can potentially overcome the 2- D nanosheet problem of restacking and forming irreversible agglomerates.323 Various methods, e.g. self-assembly and template-assisted synthesis, have been successfully employed. Three-dimensional graphene via self-assembly can be performed by hydrothermal treatment of dispersed GO sheets.324 By increasing the reduction time during the hydrothermal process, the oxygen functional groups on GO disappear slowly, thus permitting the restoration of conjugated structures. The increasing hydrophobicity and π−π interaction subsequently induce self-assembly of the nanosheets, providing a 3-D graphene with pore sizes from submicrometer to several micrometers. The self-assembled 3-D graphene tends to have a hydrophilic surface because oxygen functional groups of GO tend to encapsulate water and orient themselves outward, which facilitates further conjugation of biomolecules. In contrast, the template-assisted synthesis based techniques require a support structure such as PS microspheres,325 Ni powders,326 and porous Ni foam327 for collecting GO through self-assembly or annealing, or the CVD process. Subsequently, the support will be removed by dissolution in a proper solvent. Here, the pore size can be very well controlled by the pore size of the template. It should be noticed that the surface of 3-D graphene from template-directed CVD is highly hydrophobic, which in turn means that it requires surface activation prior to use in bio-related applications. Owing to its excellent electrical property, 3-D graphene has become a powerful interface for developing high performance electrochemical sensors, in particular as a transducer328,329 or supporting other useful functional nanomaterials.330−332
5.1.4.2.2. Nanofiber Mats. In contrast to most 1- or 2-D materials, nanofibers can easily bridge into 3-D structures as they can be centimeter to meters in length. Nanofibers in 3-D nanostructure form with high porosity materials and can be obtained by various techniques, e.g. phase separation and template synthesis, as previously mentioned in section 5.1.2.4. Among them, electrospinning stands out as it can produce continuous nanofibers with diameters from tens to hundreds of nanometers and lengths from several centimeters to meters. The technique is simple and cost-effective, highly suitable for integration into electrochemical systems, and scalable. Electrospinning produces nonwoven nanofiber mats, simply creating a 3-D porous structure in which advantages of 1-D and 3-D structures can be realized. A wide variety of electrospun 3-D nanofibers, including conducting and nonconducting polymeric nanofibers, have been used in electrochemical biosensors as a transducer and as solid support for carrying desired functionalities. Conducting nanof ibers include metallic nanofibers, metal oxide nanofibers, CNFs, and conducting-nanofiber-based conjugated polymers. They exhibit excellent electrical conductivity and are hence widely exploited as transducers in electrochemical biosensors.
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.8b00172 Chem. Rev. 2019, 119, 120−194
143
Preparation of metallic and metallic oxide nanofibers by electrospinning typically involves the electrospinning of metal salt containing polymers and post-treatment processes. For example, metallic copper nanofibers can be prepared through the following steps: (1) precursor nanofibers containing copper acetate dissolved in poly(vinyl acetate) are electrospun onto a glass substrate; (2) polymer nanofibers with copper precursors are heated at 500 °C in air for 2 h to remove all the polymer components (the process is termed “calcination”), transforming the nanofibers to dark brown CuO nanofibers; and (3) CuO nanofibers are reduced into red Cu nanofibers after annealing in an H2 atmosphere at 300 °C for 1 h. 333 Fabrication of metal oxide nanofibers can proceed in the same way but excluding step 3. A review article on electrospun metal oxide nanoparticles and their use in electrochemical sensing has recently been published by Mondal and Sharma.334 In addition to thermal treatment, it is possible to fabricate metallic nanofibers by an electroless deposition technique. Here, metal precursor (e.g., HAuCl4 for gold nanofibers) is dissolved into non-water-soluble polymers.335 Then the asspun nanofibers are immersed in a reducing agent solution to form nucleation seeds followed by subsequent electroless metal deposition. The technique is more favorable than thermal treatment as it allows in situ fabrication of metallic nanofibers onto electrodes; besides, they have lower electrical conductivity as a result of the nonconducting nanofiber backbone. Similar to other carbon materials, CNFs are of interest in electrochemical sensing as they have high electrical conductivity, have a wide potential window, show minimal surface
fouling, have high stability, and have low material costs. The CVD technique is known to generate CNFs with high quality (see also Figure 19-7), but the low production yield and the requirement of expensive equipment are major obstacles. CNFs prepared by electrospinning technique have hence attracted more attention in electrochemical sensing. Various polymer precursors, e.g. polyacrylonitrile (PAN), polyimide (PI), poly(vinyl alcohol) (PVA), and poly(vinylidene fluoride) (PVDF), can be electrospun and converted into carbon via either thermal carbonization265,336 or laser-induced carbonization.337 Zhao and co-workers successfully integrated electrospun CNFs onto GCE and demonstrated its potential utility in anodic stripping analysis of Cd2+ and Pb2+.338 Compared to the bare electrode, an 8-fold signal enhancement was reported for Pb2+ detection. In addition to pristine electrospun CNFs, addition of metal salts into electrospun nanofiber precursors and thermal carbonization of the as-spun nanofibers can facilitate the in situ formation of metal nanoparticle catalyst embedded CNFs, expanding their utility in nonenzymatic electrochemical sensing.339−341
Electrospun conducting nanofibers based on conjugated polymers have been extensively applied to electrochemical sensors due to their facile synthesis, diverse structure, high flexibility, light weight, and low cost.332 Even though the electrical conductivity of conjugated conducting nanofibers is not as good as those of electrospun CNFs and metallic nanofibers, the fabrication process requires fewer steps and mild conditions, allowing one-step fabrication of biomolecule functionalized conductive nanofibers. The electrical conduc-
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.8b00172 Chem. Rev. 2019, 119, 120−194
144
tivity of electrospun conducting nanofibers can be increased by incorporation of an electroactive filler such as graphene, CNTs, or metal nanoparticles.182,342,343
Nonconducting nanof ibers are favorable material to use as a solid support and filtering membrane owing to their high porosity and immense surface area. With the advancement of polymer chemistry in which useful coupling moieties can be introduced into a polymer chain, nonconductive nanofibers are an interesting host material for bioreceptors344 or (bio)catalyst immobilization,345,346 providing a large number of analyte binding/catalytic sites which consequently improve detection sensitivity. Functional additives can be incorporated during or after nanofiber fabrication. Inherent properties of polymers such as the presence of charges on nanofiber surfaces also allow efficient capturing of analytes with opposite charges and effective repelling of nonspecific binding in sample preparation.347,348 Furthermore, our research group has recently demonstrated that electrospun nanofiber mats can assist fluid mixing in microfluidic systems.349 These investigations have proved the capability of nanoporous materials in enhancing the collision rate between the nanomaterial and the analyte of interest which is required in the development of highperformance electrochemical sensing. 5.1.4.3. Nanocontainers. Nanocontainers are typically larger than 100 nm but are often nanostructured. Their major characteristic is their ability to load functional species, e.g. enzymes, redox markers, and nanoparticles, by entrapping them inside their nanosized pore, encapsulating the species inside the inner cavity, or anchoring them at their surface. Typically, these loaded species can later be released through physical or chemical triggering. These features make them attractive to use as nanocarriers for electroactive labeling in which high loading capacity and stability inside nanocontainers dramatically enhance detection sensitivity. In addition, selectively accommodating functional molecules based on size and affinity make nanocontainers a good candidate for sample preparation, e.g. in bioseparations, especially in chromatography. A variety of different nanocontainers have been employed in electrochemical biosensing that range from mesoporous beads to phospholipid membrane vesicles. Microsphere particles or capsules such as those made from silica or PS with typical pore sizes between 2 and 50 nm (termed “mesoporous”) are interesting in electrochemical biosensors because of their nanosized pores and tunable surface functionality. They can serve as a host for loading electroactive nanoparticles350,351 and redox markers.352−355 High loading capacity coupled with controlled-release ability thus enables remarkable signal amplification. In addition, the mesoporous silica particles can be used as an immobilized matrix for enzyme356 and a mediator,357 facilitating efficient electron transfer to electrodes. Vesicles are spherical supramolecular assemblies that form by self-organization of amphiphilic building blocks in aqueous solution.358 Typical sizes of these vesicle range from 25 to 50 nm for small unilamellar vesicles (SUVs), from 100 nm to 1 μm for large unilamellar vesicles (LUVs), and from 1 to 200 μm for “giant” vesicles.359 Lipids360 and polymers361 can be used as the building blocks for nanovesicle formations. Liposomes (Figure 28), made of phospholipids, are the most well-known nanovesicles and have been intensively exploited in electrochemical biosensors.362 Self-organization of phospholipid bilayers allows loading of a large number of water-soluble electroactive molecules or enzymes inside the liposome cavity.
Upon release of the encapsulant through physical or chemical means, an intense electrochemical signal can be obtained. This makes liposome-encapsulated electrochemical markers an excellent candidate to be used as a signal amplification agent for electrochemical biosensors as they do not provide any signal until specifically triggered. Thus, background signals can easily be obtained and subtracted from the analytical signal. For potassium ferrohexacyanide approximately 104 molecules/ liposome could be accommodated in 100−150 nm liposomes, which was first reported by Durst et al.363 and was later increased to 105−106 molecules in 200−250 nm liposomes.364 Alternatively, efforts have been made to anchor electrochemical labels onto liposome surfaces either by direct conjugation to the building block365 or by postmodification via covalent bonding to liposomes.366 In addition, with the advancement of conjugation technology and the commercial availability of functional lipid-tagged BREs, e.g. nucleic acid, antibody, and biotin, they can easily be introduced to liposome surfaces, which facilitates electrochemical detection with high selectivity. Our research group has successfully implemented liposome encapsulated redox markers in miniaturized systems as shown in ref 367. Magnetic-bead-based separation facilitates the capture of a target bound reporter probe inside microchannels. Redox markers are released from liposomes via a detergent enabling electrochemical signal generation at the downstream electrode. Here, the microfluidic system enables convenient liposome-based bioassays; thus the platform has been applied to a number of different sensing systems.364,368−370
Even though liposomes are very attractive signal amplifiers for electrochemical biosensors, they can encounter some issues, such as colloidal stability which causes leakage or liposome fusion when inappropriate lipids and osmolality conditions are chosen.360,371
5.1.5. Nanostructured Arrays. 5.1.5.1. Nanopores. Nanopores, with a pore size similar to the size of biomolecules (1.5−40 nm),372 enable a label-free electrochemical biosensing platform in which the extremely small volume of the nanopore’s interior allows for the observation of physical and chemical properties of those species translocating or residing within a nanopore.366 In general, a single nanopore embedded in a membrane is placed between two electrochemical chambers containing conducting buffer. The application of voltage to the system drives the flow of electrolyte ions through the nanopore in which the conductivity is measured.
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.8b00172 Chem. Rev. 2019, 119, 120−194
145
Similar to a conventional Coulter counter principle, translocation of analytes passing through the pore will alter the system’s conductivity. Different detection strategies of biomolecules with the help of nanopores can be established based on size,373 shape,374 or charge of the analyte.375
The nature of the nanopore can differ significantly and can be made of natural biological molecules or can be nanoengineered. Solid-state nanopores (nanometer-sized apertures fabricated in thin solid-state membrane as shown in Figure 29- 1) and protein nanopores (α-hemolysin embedded in lipid bilayer membrane as illustrated in Figure 29-2) have been widely fabricated for biosensing applications, especially for proteins.374,376 Yet, solid-state nanopores are more favorable due to a truly tunable shape and pore size, and most importantly, greater physical robustness in a broad range of chemical conditions and applied voltages. Furthermore, the introduction of bioreceptors at the entrance or inside the inner wall of a nanopore377 provides a real-time, selective biosensing platform for monitoring the captured analyte through the change of conductance or resistance. Even though single nanopores offer the opportunity for single molecule detection as shown in many reports,378 they are difficult to fabricate, and real-world sample analysis is questionable, which overall currently limits their use to research. Nanopore arrays have
therefore been employed for applications especially in biosensor-based nanochannel platforms.379 Here, solid-state nanopore arrays made from anodized alumina membranes are extensively used.380
In an alternative approach to the measurement of intrinsic conductance altered by the analyte, nanopore arrays have been used to simply modify electrode surfaces. The presence of analytes inside the nanochannels inhibits the accessibility of electroactive species in solution toward the electrode surface. The increase in impedance and the decrease in current response can hence be monitored. It should be noted that the size of the pore must be very close to the analyte of interest in order to see a significant change as demonstrated by Vlassiouk et al.381 Alternatively, when using a membrane with large pore sizes, the sensitivity can be enhanced through introducing additional probe-nanoparticle tags (e.g., AuNPs) for better blockage.382 The detection sensitivity could be further improved when using AuNP-enhanced silver deposition.383
The use of nanopore arrays to modify electrodes also potentially reduces the interference from large molecules in blood samples to penetrate into the electrode surface, alleviating electrode fouling (Figure 30).383−385
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.8b00172 Chem. Rev. 2019, 119, 120−194
146
Recently, Rajeev et al. reviewed the biosensing systems that have benefited from utilizing nanoporous anodized alumina membranes for the detection of clinical biomarkers.386
5.1.5.2. Nanopillars. Nanopillars, vertically aligned nanowire arrays on a lateral surface, have typical diameters and heights around a few hundred nanometers and submicrometer to a few micrometers, respectively.387 Their structure and morphologies introduce a significant surface area while maintaining the overall dimensions of the original substrate. In particular, nanopillars are very attractive to use in electrochemical biosensors as the increased active surface area can increase the current output similar to nanowires, and provide large surface area for modification of biomolecules or other chemical functionalities.388 As demonstrated by Anandan et al., a gold nanopillar electrode showed a 7-fold increase in its sensitivity compared with a flat electrode.389 It is worth mentioning that when vertically aligned nanostructures, especially with high aspect ratios, are exposed to liquid environment, the capillary force between the nanostructures and the liquid medium will bunch nanopillars together, leading to a decrease of active surface area. To overcome this problem, Anandan et al. used an aqueous-based electrochemical deposition technique to fabricate nanopillar array structures; nanopillars with aspect ratios as high as 30 could be obtained with sufficient mechanical stability.389
In general, when using nanopillar structures with a very narrow spacing as electrodes, similar to nanoporous electrode, the charge transfer properties, i.e. diffusion- or non-diffusioncontrolled system, indicate the actual active area. Schröper et al. found that the enhanced active surface area of electrodes with nanopillars (space between pillars = 23 nm) compared to the flat surface were found to be 1.45 and 5.9 times those for diffusion-controlled and non-diffusion-controlled systems, respectively.390 Furthermore, a very small volume between pillars can hinder analytes’ access to the entire nanopillars. Lotwala and Ji provide a good overview for further reading regarding the effects of nanopillar introduction on the electrochemistry of electrodes.391
In addition to being a transducer, nanopillars can enhance cell adhesion and growth as well as the ability to penetrate cells,387 which make them very attractive for biomedical research. Nanopillars for cell capturing, especially for circulating tumor cells (CTCs), have been extensively reported because cells favor the binding on nanotopographic surfaces.392,393
5.1.5.3. Nanoneedles. Nanoneedles are sometimes classified as part of the group of nanopillars387 or the other way around; however, due to their unique shape and function they deserve to be discussed separately. Nanoneedles are different from nanopillars mainly in terms of their tip size. A vertically conical shaped nanostructure with a sharp end should be used to describe a nanoneedle. For example, nanoneedles with 6−9° tapered shape, sharp 2−5 nm tips, and 4 μm in length and 600 nm wide at the base have been reported.394 Nanoneedle arrays have been widely exploited in sensing of biological systems395 where the major advantages are attributed to the high aspect ratio of nanoneedles and the ability to penetrate into cells with minimal invasiveness. The high aspect ratio causes less damage when the device is inserted into cells or skin and increases the sensing area for monitoring intracellular analytes. Nanoneedle arrays are currently of interest for the development of wearable biosensors as can be seen from an ongoing project developed by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research
Organisation (CSIRO), Australia.396 Nanoneedle arrays made of silicon are especially promising for minimally invasive devices for the detection of specific cancer markers from skin. In particular, combining the nanoneedle array and electrochemical biosensing technology, construction of a wearable and automated device is able to facilitate the detection of early tumor recurrence.
5.1.6. Hybrid Nanostructures. Hybrid nanomaterials describe the combination of nanomaterials aiming to improve or develop desired functional properties in which the individual component cannot offer such functionalities.397 The combination of various classes of nanomaterials/ nanostructure opens the possibility to construct high performance electrochemical biosensors in which synergistic benefits of the combined nanomaterials can be exploited. Hybrid nanomaterials have been extensively established as a transducer, signal amplifier, and label in electrochemical biosensors. In this section, examples of the combined nanomaterials to produce new or useful functionality in electrochemical biosensors due to their synergistic effects that does not obtain from the individual components will be given. Our research group successfully incorporated ferromagnetic metal oxide nanoparticles into the lipid bilayer of fluorescent dye-encapsulating liposomes398 and applied them as reporter probes for binding assays. Besides a dramatic signal enhancement realized from marker-encapsulated liposomes, diffusion limitations of binding between the reporter probe bound targets and immobilized BREs could be alleviated when a magnetic field was applied underneath the surface, leading to 8-fold shorter incubation time compared to without having a magnet and a more than 10 times lower limit of detection. The format is attractive for electrochemical biosensors where BREs are immobilized on electrode surfaces.370 Here, magnetic liposomes should also enable the close proximity between released redox markers and electrode surfaces, serving as a powerful nanocarrier. Label-free sensor-based EIS typically suffers from low sensitivity, particularly when detecting small molecules by observing conformation changes of aptamers. Peinetti et al. have overcome this problem through a controlled architecture of nanoelectrodes.399 Herein, isolated AuNPs (∼2 nm) were electrochemically synthesized inside nanoporous alumina (11 ± 1 nm pore diameter and a 35 ± 4 nm interpore distance) and served as a transducer and immobilization surface for a DNA aptamer recognizing adenosine monophosphate (AMP). The aptamer sequence contains 27 nucleotides that exhibit two possible structural states, either a random coil (a flexible cord of 1 nm diameter and 10 nm length) or a stem−loop structure (the aptamer bound two AMPs creating a structure 2 nm in diameter). The proposed electrode configuration ensures that the interfacial electron transfer is limited to the gold surface which enables the monitoring of a slight change of aptamer conformation upon binding on AuNPs (Figure 31). This work demonstrates well the synergistic benefit that can be realized through nanoparticles and nanopore arrays. Electrodes modified with MWNTs are prone to surface fouling during electrochemical measurements, especially due to the accumulation of oxidized byproducts such as DA-oquinone and N-acetyl-p-quinoneimine. Cheemalapati et al. have overcome this problem by employing a nanocomposite with multiwalled CNTs and GO.161 The oxygen-containing groups in GO play a significant role in preventing the accumulation of the oxidized byproducts as well as promoting
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.8b00172 Chem. Rev. 2019, 119, 120−194
147
good dispersion stability of the nanocomposite itself. In addition, the authors also demonstrated that the nanocomposite showed superior electrocatalytic activity toward the oxidation of DA and paracetamol, when compared with either pristine MWNT or GO. Furthermore, MWNTs prevented the aggregation of graphene during synthesis. The network of MWNTs was simultaneously introduced into a GO suspension prepared during chemical reduction by hydrazine. Finally, the nanocomposite modified electrode exhibited a greater electrochemical performance toward H2O2 detection when compared to using reduced graphene and MWNTs alone. A composite nanomaterial is made from at least two different materials and bears new characteristics that are not found in the original separate materials. Many examples can be found in sensors and analytical applications, e.g. where hydrogels are doped with CNTs, polymeric nanofibers doped with metal nanoparticles, or metal−organic frameworks (MOFs) of different origins are merged to form a new material. MOFs are an emerging candidate that attract
considerable attention for application in electrochemical sensing. They are a hybrid material built from metal ions with well-defined coordination geometry and organic bridging ligands400 as shown in Figure 32. MOFs have been employed as a signal tracer, catalysts, a signal carrier, and an immobilization surface in electrochemical sensors. For example, Au-SH-SiO2 nanoparticles were immobilized on Cu-MOF to construct an electrochemical sensor for Lcysteine.401 Cu-MOF alone possesses electrocatalytic ability toward the oxidation of cysteine, generating a peak at 0.6 V, but introduction of Au-SH-SiO2 nanoparticles dramatically enhanced electroanalytical performance as shown by a lower oxidation potential (0.4 V) and 10 times higher current. Their network structures provide ultrahigh porosity, large surface areas, and a large pore volume, which together play a key role for hosting electroactive markers and immobilizing bioreceptors. Thus, the composite metals can themselves act as signal tracer and catalyst. High chemical and thermal stability are additional advantages that make MOFs excellent candidates for developing robust electrochemical biosensors. An excellent review article on the application of MOFs in electrochemical biosensors has been provided recently.402
Overall, composite nanomaterials are such a diverse group of materials that a cohesive discussion of their properties is not possible here. Instead, they are covered with specific examples in section 5.2.

sections.heading: 2013 to 2018)
sections.text:
So far, focus was put onto actual biosensors and LOC systems. However, many examples for the successful use of nanostructures and nanomaterials in mere bioassays have been published in the past five years. Bioassays obviously have a much broader analytical definition as they encompass all experimental procedures studying biological effects or quantifying components in biological systems,404 where nanomaterials and nanostructures can offer diverse functionalities useful for enhancing ultimate analytical performance. In this section, we therefore focus on the state-of-the-art of nanomaterials and nanostructures that are currently used in bioassays but which have the true possibility to be implemented into LOC systems.
5.2.1. Application for Sample Preparation (Examples). Low concentrations of analytes and the unavoidable presence of matrix interference make sample preparation including separation and preconcentration a necessity in promoting highly selective and sensitive electrochemical biosensors. Nanomaterials with various features can provide valuable solutions with sample preparation functionality in electrochemical biosensors. We focus on two major strategies of separation, i.e. size selection using nanoporous structures
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.8b00172 Chem. Rev. 2019, 119, 120−194
148
and affinity-assisted separation with and without an applied external magnetic field. 5.2.1.1. Analyte Separation Based on Size Selection Functionalities of Nanomaterials. A wide variety of nanoporous structures have been utilized for sample preparation purposes. This section will provide recent developments of nanoporous structures that show promise for their integration into miniaturized systems. Small organic analytes such as drugs, pesticides, and antibiotics can be detected in complex media containing large interfering molecules without sample pretreatment as reported by Su’s group.384,405 Permselective membranes consisting of highly ordered and vertically aligned silica mesochannels and micelles were directly placed over electrodes. These limited access and adsorption of large interfering proteins on the electrode surface and thus prevented biofouling. Similarly, Yan et al. fabricated vertically aligned silica mesochannels with ordered surfactant micelles which fully cover inside the inner wall,405 enabling the same permselective strategy in terms of both molecular size and chemistry. Here, only small and neutral/hydrophobic molecules with sizes less than 3 nm were able to permeate the channels toward the underlying ITO electrodes and were then detected by voltammetry. The authors applied their platform to the detection of trace pesticides (paraoxon) and environmental pollutants (m-nitrochlorobenzene) in soil dispersions. In addition, they were able to detect antibiotics (chloramphenicol) in complex media such as milk and human blood serum. In 2016, the group also proved the possibility for direct detection of drugs in human whole blood (Figure 33).384 The micelles with their hydrophobic hydrocarbon cores effectively extracted neutral lipophilic molecules from aqueous media, and the extracted redox molecules underwent a fast electron transfer at the membrane/ITO electrode interface as indicated by EIS measurements. Chloramphenicol in unprocessed human whole blood was detected with a detection limit of only 37.7 ppb. The stability of the electrodes with signal
retention of 79% was achieved over 45 min testing, whereas bare ITO exhibited only 24.5%. Size-based separation enhanced by the application of an electric field is typically done using gel electrophoresis. Miniaturization of this strategy can be accomplished in a variety of ways and has been reviewed previously.406−408 Nanomaterials can replace the polymer solution which significantly simplifies the fabrication of the systems, which is related to the difficulty of filling a polymer solution into small separation channels. Furthermore, nanomaterials have shown to broaden the otherwise narrow separation size ranges as reviewed in ref 409. Rahong et al. have developed a rigid 3-D network structure composed of solid nanowires within a microchannels that can easily be applied to DNA separation and could easily be connected to downstream electrochemical detection (Figure 34).410 Pore sizes of the nanowire network structure were adjusted by controlling the number of growth cycles, enabling rapid analysis of DNA in a dc electric field for a uniquely broad DNA length (100 bp−166 kbp). The ability to tune nanowire spatial density significantly determined electrophoretic behaviors of different sized DNA molecules in this work; i.e. the 3-D networks with growth cycles of 1, 3, and 5 could selectively separate DNA sizes of 10−166 kbp, 5−10 kbp, and 100 bp−1 kbp, respectively. The developed method can define the spatial location and density of the nanostructure within the microchannels, which offers an opportunity to exploit the 3-D network as a bioseparation unit inside microfluidic bioanalytical systems and is clearly not limited to DNA analysis. Another electrophoretic separation principle has been applied to the analysis of microRNAs (miRNAs). These are approximately 22-nucleotide-long, noncoding, single-stranded RNA molecules, and have been identified as potential biomarkers for diagnosis and prognosis of cancer, as their levels in bodily fluid are correlated with the initiation and progression of cancer.411 In general, the procedure of miRNA extraction includes (1) disruption of samples in a denaturing
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.8b00172 Chem. Rev. 2019, 119, 120−194
149
lysis buffer, (2) extraction by acid−phenol chloroform for removing other cellular components, and (3) filtration through silica membrane for selective capturing miRNA from rRNA, tRNA, and mRNA. Obviously, the technique is timeconsuming and labor-intensive. Wu et al. proposed a hybrid structure of nanopillars and nanoslits integrated inside an electrophoresis microchip to enable high speed (millisecond) separation of miRNA from a mixture of total RNA and genomic DNA, extracted from cultured HeLa cells (Figure 35).412 The as-prepared sieve matrix consisted of the nanopillars (250 nm in diameter and 100 nm in height) with a space distance of 750 nm inside the nanoslits (100 nm in height and 25 μm in width). Even though the authors have proposed the established microchip for pretreatment of semiconductor nanopore DNA sequencing which requires high-speed reading, this work is also a promising platform for miRNA separation in microfluidic-based electrochemical biosensor systems. An equally challenging separation task, i.e. separation of specific cell types from each other, has been demonstrated using nanograss electrodes. CTCs are cells that are released from metastatic tumors into the bloodstream. The number of
CTCs present in blood is very small when compared to the high number of red blood cells (RBCs) and white blood cells (WBCs). Especially, the comparable sizes of CTCs and WBCs (>12 μm) make filtration-based size-exclusion systems difficult to achieve. Recently, Hosseini et al. fabricated a microfluidic channel containing silicon nanograss (SiNG) which allowed the discrimination of CTCs and WBCs based on their intrinsic membrane capacitance by monitoring impedance magnitude, which cannot be obtained by other size-exclusion-based filtration techniques (Figure 36).413
Daggumati et al. have exploited the unique features of nanoporous gold electrodes such as being biofouling resilient, having high electrical conductivity, and having high active surface areas to develop the purification system for specific DNA sequences which are possible to serve as a detection system, too (Figure 37).414 Herein, nanoporous gold electrodes were modified with 26-mer DNA probes via thiol gold based linker and exposed to a target DNA sequence in a mixture of large interfering DNA fragments and fetal bovine serum. Excluding the large interfering DNA and proteins by a nanoporous gold structure with a median pore radius of 15 nm could effectively prevent biofouling, giving high purity of target DNA probe hybrids after capturing. Electrochemical cleavage of the thiol−gold linkage facilitated elution of the DNA hybrids for further analysis. The platform offers a great opportunity to integrate both purification and electrochemical detection steps into miniaturized analytical systems. So et al. used a very different approach in which the pointy and sharp nature of their nanomaterial caused mechanical lysis of cells followed by efficient nucleic acid extraction. Specifically, they present a handheld device consisting of a ZnO nanowire-decorated silicon porous membrane which is
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.8b00172 Chem. Rev. 2019, 119, 120−194
150
capable of isolating DNA by selective adsorption to the silica surface immediately after cell lysis via ultrasharp tips of the nanowires (Figure 38-1).415 The as-prepared membrane was directly integrated into commercial syringe filter holders allowing continuous mechanical cell lysis and rapid DNA isolation without the assistance of power sources, lysis reagents, and routine centrifugation. The purification process could be done within 5 min resulting in high DNA purity, whereas a commercial kit takes more than an hour. Similar ideas were also demonstrated by the same research group where hierarchical silicon nanospike membranes (HSSM) were employed to disrupt cells (Figure 38-2).416 In this work, the author proved that the cell lysates prepared from HSSM’s mechanical lysis had quantitatively higher intracellular protein and nucleic acid concentrations than those obtained by
conventional acoustic and chemical lysis methods. These examples demonstrate well the potential of nanoneedle-like structures for assisting sample preparation.
5.2.1.2. Analyte Separation Based on Affinity-Assisted Separation Functionalities of Nanomaterials. 5.2.1.2.1. Magnetically Enhanced Separation. MNPs are a well-known solid support that is mostly utilized for sample preparation in bioanalytical processes,217 and typically based on the interactions of immobilized biological probes. Magnetic preconcentration can minimize interferents from sample matrixes as well as attract analyte-biorecognition complexes toward the electrode surface through the application of an external magnetic field. A number of publications on electrochemical biosensors have successfully shown the efficacy of MNPs in separating the analyte of interest from highly complex matrixes such as whole blood,417,418 urine,419 soil,420 food421,422 and beverage423 samples, and so on. Commercially available MNPs functionalized with various surface groups or biological probes are a good indication for the maturity and success of this research approach. While no new configurations/formats on their use in electrochemical biosensors have been reported in the past five years, research has focused on ameliorating a major disadvantage and avoiding the numerous steps for cleaning that require operator input. Detection systems have been developed that allow automation with minimal sample handling and high throughput capability. In general for sample preparation prior to electrochemical detection, MNPs are modified with capture probes such as antibodies, receptors, and DNA probes. After hybridization or binding of the capture probes to their corresponding targets, reporter probes are introduced and bound to the magnetic nanoparticle−target complex. For multianalyte detection by electrochemical sensing, multiple washing and reagent additions make the method time-consuming and labor-
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.8b00172 Chem. Rev. 2019, 119, 120−194
151
intensive, leading to low-throughput assay. Tang et al. demonstrated a high-throughput platform with multiplexed detection of cancer biomarker proteins in which MNPs served both as a separator and as an enzyme label carrier (Figure 39).424 Here, they demonstrated amperometric detection of four proteins employing 300 nm MNPs decorated with secondary antibodies (Ab2) and HRP labels, designated as Ab2-MNP-HRP beads. The beads for four prostate cancer biomarker proteins, including prostate specific antigen (PSA), prostate specific membrane antigen (PSMA), interleukin-6 (IL-6), and platelet factor-4 (PF-4) were combined and reconstituted in phosphate buffer and incubated with the protein standard mixtures to capture the target proteins. The solution of captured analytes was transferred to a reagent reservoir and withdrawn to the sensing arrays functionalized with corresponding primary antibodies by a syringe. Ring magnets were fitted beneath the arrays to facilitate transport of the MNPs conjugates onto the sensor surfaces. After incubation and washing steps, introduction of a HRP substrate solution (hydroquinone mediator/hydrogen peroxide) allowed the generation of electrochemical signals. The device enabled the detection of four proteins (six replicate measures) at eight concentrations included in calibration curves within 60 min (from the offline capture of antigens to quantitative results). Jeong et al. demonstrated an interesting application to such a system by focusing on the isolation of exosomes.425 Exosomes are small lipid/protein extracellular vesicles that are seen as a potential marker for early cancer detection because they can encapsulate labile cancer markers, e.g. RNA. Exosomes are small (50−150 nm) and have a low density making them extremely difficult to isolate from plasma. Jeong et al.
developed an integrated magnetic−electrochemical exosome test system, so-called iMEX, that combines magnetic separation and electrochemical detection in the device (Figure 40). Owing to bead-based magnetic enrichment, it offers fast binding kinetics between antibodies and exosomes as well as concentrating signal sources on the electrodes, and thus enhanced the detection sensitivity. The sensor required only 10 μL of plasma samples and generated readouts within 1 h. In addition, the magnetic nanoparticle-bound exosomes could be recovered simply through elution or lysis for downstream molecular analyses in tandem with iMEX. The proposed iMEX features an overall low device cost (<$50), affordability, scalability, and comprehensive exosome analyses which is highly promising for deepening insights into tumor biology and accelerating effective cancer management in clinical applications. Barallat et al. developed a novel magnetic switch integrated with electrodes and electrical connectors for amperometric detection of myeloperoxidase (MPO), a marker for diagnosis and stratification of acute coronary syndrome, in human plasma (Figure 41).426 The vertical displacement of a permanent magnet under the transducer assists with operation of the magnetic field (on vs off) which assists in confining the magnetic nanoparticle−analyte complex over the WE and facilitating electrode washing and regeneration. Finally, Torrente-Rodriǵuez and colleagues have developed an amperometric magnetic biosensor for the simultaneous determination of two biomarkers associated with salivary oral cancer, protein IL-8 and its mRNA (IL-8 mRNA) in undiluted human saliva samples,427 which is a good example for typical application of magnetic beads (MBs) in electrochemical
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.8b00172 Chem. Rev. 2019, 119, 120−194
152
biosensors (Figure 42). The MBs bearing the HRP-labeled sandwich immunocomplexes or DNA duplexes were magnetically captured on the corresponding electrode (WE 1 and WE 2) of the dual screen-printed carbon electrode (SPdCE). Amperometric detection at −0.20 V of the catalytic current produced upon H2O2 addition using hydroquinone (HQ) as redox mediator in solution was used to monitor each target analyte concentration. The results from the developed magnetobiosensor were consistent with those obtained from the corresponding ELISA standard method for IL-8 analysis of saliva sample. 5.2.1.2.2. Nonmagnetic Strategies for NanomaterialEnhanced Separation. In most cases, the analyte separation process without magnetic property consists of three major steps including exposure of nanomaterials to the sample, interaction between the nanomaterials and analytes taking place, washing steps, and releasing of target analytes. Colloidal nanoparticles without magnetic property, e.g. GO, metallic nanoparticles, and silica nanoparticles, have not been widely reported to assist in the separation of analytes in miniaturized
systems as the separation process typically includes filtering membranes or centrifugation. Moreover, packing nanoparticles into devices is not favorable owing to high back pressure. As a result, application of colloidal nanoparticles as concentrators are not suitable in dynamic extraction modes. However, incorporation of colloidal nanoparticles to a support especially with high porosity will enable their uses as physically efficient concentrators. Intrinsic chemistries and postsynthesis functionalization of nanomaterials provide strategies to tailor the materials toward capturing specific analytes, which make them suitable for extraction. For example, AuNPs exhibited strong affinity toward Hg2+,384 thiol functional groups,428 and polyaromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs).429 Titanium dioxide and other metal oxide composites have been successfully applied to separate trace elements from contaminated environmental samples.430 In some instances the strong affinity between intrinsic chemical functionalities of nanoparticles and analytes can be coupled with electrochemical detection techniques such as adsorptive stripping voltammetry which makes the nanomaterial an
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.8b00172 Chem. Rev. 2019, 119, 120−194
153
excellent choice for sensor development. Further examples demonstrate unique abilities of nanomaterials for analyte isolation, but do not couple the electrochemical detection directly into the same nanomaterial. Graphene oxide nanoplatelets (GONPs) with extremely
sharp edges exhibited an unique functionality in extraction of
the overexpressed guanine synthesized in the cytoplasm of leukemia cells (Figure 43).431 The sharp edges of GONPs allow physical damage of cell membranes, which resulted in the release of cytoplasmic contents. As GONPs have strong affinity toward nucleic acids via π−π stacking, van der Waals forces, and hydrogen bonds, the GONPs could separate bound
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.8b00172 Chem. Rev. 2019, 119, 120−194
154
guanine belonging to released DNA and RNA molecules from free guanine released from cells by centrifugation. The free guanine in plasma was then determined electrochemically through guanine oxidation. A combined separator/detector functionality is also envisioned here. In a more general fashion, forces relating to opposite charges can be exploited, especially since a release of bound analyte can be realized by simple pH adjustments. The concept has been successfully applied to DNA,188,432 proteins,433,434 liposomes,347 and bacterial cells.348 In addition, Liu et al. recently reported that size-selective DNA separation was feasible through adjusting the ionic strength of the solution which consequently alters the electrostatic interactions between DNA fragments and the lysine-functionalized surface of silica particles (Figure 44).435
Another example is the use of PANI/PS membranes made by electrospinning of PS and subsequent in situ chemical polymerization of aniline for DNA extraction.188 PANI in emeraldine salt form contains positively charged imine groups that are able to electrostatically attract the negatively charged phosphate groups of the DNA strands. Moreover, the electrostatic interaction between PANI and DNA can easily be destroyed via deprotonation of PANI in an alkaline solution, leading to desorption of DNA from the fibers. The electrostatic repulsion between the deprotonated PANI and the phosphate groups of the DNA could be enhanced by introducing SDS anions in the alkaline solution. This group packed the PANI/PS membranes into a spin column, generating a convenient procedure for DNA separation (Figure 45). Here, four disks of highly hydrophobic electrospun PS were placed underneath the PANI/PS membranes, acting as a physical barrier to assist with the retention of DNA solution, and thus allowing for better interaction between DNA and PANI. The authors pointed out that the procedure was faster than the batch mode and that their spin column had a 3 times higher adsorption efficiency. This was likely due to the high surface area, high porosity, and the intrinsic chemistry of the
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.8b00172 Chem. Rev. 2019, 119, 120−194
155
PANI/PS membrane leading to high DNA adsorption capacity and quick adsorption−desorption times. Our group recently demonstrated the use of negatively charged nanofibers functionalized with antibodies against Escherichia coli K12 as a preconcentration module for bacteria detection in a microfluidic system.348 The retention experiments were carried out by flowing the solution containing diluted bacteria through the microfluidic channels and plating the effluent on agar plates. The negatively charged nanofibers made from PVA and poly(methyl vinyl ether-alt-maleic anhydride) (poly(MVE/MA)) were fabricated by electrospinning. Available carboxyl groups on the nanofiber surfaces served as a chemical linker for the antibody conjugation and repellent moieties for the negatively charged E. coli, thus minimizing the amount of nonspecific retention within the channels. The 3-D morphology with respect to pore size and density could be controlled and ensured that the cells were not retained due to size but only based on surface properties. The work illustrates nicely the control, functionality, and integratability of nanomaterials with miniaturized detection platforms. 5.2.2. Application for Immobilization (Examples). In this section, we will focus on the function of nanomaterials as immobilized substrate/support for BRE and functional electroactive species, e.g. nanoparticles or nanocatalysts. 5.2.2.1. Immobilization of Biorecognition Molecules. High surface-area-to-volume ratio of nanosized materials is highly attractive to a bioreceptor’s conjugation, facilitating the accommodation of a high number of recognition sites for electrochemical biosensors. Similar to bulk materials, biorecognition molecules or functional active species can be linked to nanomaterials and nanostructures through various methods436 depending on their available surface chemistry (see also section 4). Higher loading capacity of biorecognition molecules can promote wider dynamic ranges for electrochemical signals because the binding of analytes is less likely to become saturated with their complementary immobilized probes at high sample concentrations.436,437 In addition, the immobilization of BREs onto nanomaterials is commonly carried out for nanotracers or separators. BRE immobilized MNPs have been extensively used for sample preparation and were discussed in section 5.2.1. Therefore, we present here recent progress on the application of biorecognition molecules immobilized on other nanomaterials such as carbon nanomaterials, nanoparticles, and nanoporous structures. Recently, Ali and co-workers have shown an outstanding electrochemical performance of protein detection based on EIS that could be realized by using microfluidic biosensor
integrated graphene foam (GF) modified with electrospun carbon-doped titanium dioxide nanofibers (nTiO2).
438 The combination of large specific surface area, three-dimensional conductive pathways, high porosity, and a miniaturized biosensing system enables the detection limit of 1 fM and a detection range of 1 fM−0.1 μM. The authors applied this method toward early stage detection of breast cancer biomarkers, which is important for clinical diagnosis and treatment. The epidermal growth factor receptor 2 (ErbB2) protein as a potential marker for early breast cancer diagnosis was used as a model analyte which requires such low limits of detection. The GF−nTiO2 composite was activated through O2 plasma which enabled covalent conjugation with the antiErbB2 antibodies via EDC−NHS coupling chemistry, resulting in the formation of amide bonds between the antibody and the GF−nTiO2 composite, thus enabling high stability and enhanced loading capacity of the bioreceptor (Figure 46-1). Modifying the GF with nTiO2 and antibodies increased the charge transfer resistance (Rct) and significantly reduced voltammetric signals as shown in Figure 46, parts 2a and 2b, respectively. Upon forming the immunocomplex, the negatively charged ErbB2 on the sensor surface repelled the redox species, resulting in a higher impedance signal. Thus, an increase of Rct and decrease of voltammetric signals (Fe(CN)6
3−/4− in PBS as the detection medium) were used as response signals correlating directly to the biomarker concentration in the sample (Figure 46-3). TMD sheets have been recently employed as an electrode modifier for protein immobilization. The analytical application chosen was the detection of fenitrothion, which is an organophosphate pesticide commonly used in agriculture. It inhibits the activity of acetylcholine esterase (AChE) by irreversibly binding to the active sites, preventing the lysis of neurotransmitter acetylcholine (ACh) which in turn leads to an overstimulation in the nervous system. AChE was hence immobilized on the TMDs to detect the enzyme inhibition by fenitrothion.439 In general, TMD materials exhibit two polymorph structures as shown in Figure 47-1, i.e. 2H (naturally occurring materials where the metal atom coordination is trigonal prismatic) and 1T (the metal coordination is octahedral). The former structure exhibits semiconducting properties to the material, while the latter presents a metallic character with a significantly enhanced conductivity.440 Transition of 2H → 1T in this study was carried out by chemical exfoliation using tert-butyllithium (tBuLi) as intercalator. The preparation technique generates a high content of metallic 1T-phase structures which enhanced the analytical sensitivity of the constructed electrochemical biosensors. Figure 47-2 illustrates the detection scheme of their biosensor. After depositing t-BuLi exfoliated TMD onto a GCE, glutaraldehyde was used as a cross-linker between the amine groups in AChE and t-BuLi exfoliated TMD to immobilize the enzymes as well as provide structural stability to the biosensor system. In this study, WS2 exhibited the best electroanalytical performance in comparison to MoS2, MoSe2, and WSe2 sheets that were exfoliated using the same method.
A variety of nanomaterials have been reported to help in the specific isolation of cells, a dominant topic CTC isolation from blood.443,444 The nanomaterials and nanostructures such as GO,445 nanofibers,446,447 nanopillars,448 and nanotexture surfaces449 are typically conjugated with specific antibodies
recognizing the epithelial adhesion molecule (anti-EpCAM) to then serve as an efficient separator by isolating low abundance CTCs from blood. In addition to anti-EpCAM, aptamers that have been developed to specifically recognize EpCAM are also popular, as reviewed in refs 450 and 451. Sheng et al. have
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.8b00172 Chem. Rev. 2019, 119, 120−194
157
demonstrated that AuNPs can load a number of aptamers (up to 95 aptamers per 13.6 nm sized particle), promoting enhanced molecular recognition capability via multivalent
binding (simultaneous interaction of multiple ligands on one entity with the complementary receptors on another as shown in Figure 48).452 Compared with single aptamers, a 39-fold
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.8b00172 Chem. Rev. 2019, 119, 120−194
158
increase in binding affinity toward the cancer cells was reported (dissociation constant (Kd) of 0.10 ± 0.02 nM and Kd = 3.9 ± 0.5 nM for AuNP−aptamer and single aptamers, respectively). This ultimately resulted in a greater capture efficiency for CTC isolation from a cell mixture in micro-
channels where the capture efficiencies of 49 and 92% were obtained using single aptamers and AuNP−aptamer, respectively. This work nicely illustrates the potential of nanomaterials as an effective immobilization surface for cell binding which would be useful for electrochemical-based detection techniques that require strong binding between cells and biorecognition molecules. Alternative to immobilizing common bioreceptors such as DNA probes, antibodies, aptamers, and enzymes onto nanomaterials, Park’s research group has incorporated human taste receptor proteins into the lipid bilayer of nanovesicles to create nanovesicle-based bioelectronic tongues (NBTs).160,453 In principle, the nanovesicles function as artificial cells as the protein receptors coupled with G-protein, and ion channels are embedded in the lipid bilayer. Binding to the corresponding analyte triggers the change of ion flux modulated through G proteins and adenylyl cyclase. The alteration of ion flux (Ca2+ transported through ion channel) results in a change of conductance which can be real-time monitored by SWNTFET. Figure 49-1a illustrates the sensor configuration and its components in which the functional nanovesicle was immobilized on SWNTs via 1-pyrenebutanoic acid Nhydroxysuccinimidyl ester (PSE); the successful immobiliza-
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.8b00172 Chem. Rev. 2019, 119, 120−194
159
tion was proven by the SEM image shown in Figure 49-1b. Based on this principle, this research group employed heterodimeric G-protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs) composed of human taste receptor type 1 member 2 (hTAS1R2) and human taste receptor type 1 member 3 (hTAS1R3) for sweetener detection. The control experiments in Figure 49-1d proved that all components are essential for the signal transduction of NBT. By monitoring the decrease of conductance (Figure 49-1c), this strategy enabled a biosensor
for the detection of sucrose in various samples (Dulbecco’s phosphate buffered saline (DPBS), Darjeeling tea, and coffee) as shown in Figure 49-1e. The same research group has also extended the concept to construct a duplex bioelectronic tongue (DBT) in which umami and sweet taste receptor nanovesicles were separately immobilized on the duplex graphene FET (Figure 49-2). Highly sensitive and selective responses were obtained for real-time dual detection of monosodium glutamate (MSG) and sucrose.453
