5.2.2.2. Immobilization of Functional Electroactive Species. Electroactive species such as noble nanoparticles, metal oxide nanoparticles, or nanowires can serve as catalysts for nonenzymatic sensing.188 Owing to their excellent electrical conductivity and high number of available nucleation sites, carbon nanomaterials such as graphene,454 CNTs,455 CNFs,339,340 and GF456,457 have been widely used as a support to incorporate the nanocatalyst. Their immobilization onto carbon nanomaterials can be performed via various strategies such as adsorption, electrodeposition, chemical reduction, or sputter deposition. Recently Sun and co-workers fabricated freestanding graphene−CNT hybrid paper decorated with high density Pt nanoparticles.458 The authors demonstrated its potential use for real-time amperometric monitoring H2O2 secretion by live cells (macrophages). Polymeric materials, both nonconductive and conductive, have been decorated with nanoparticle catalysts to provide new functionalities. Polymers can have a diverse range of reactive groups, which serve as adsorption or nucleation sites for the formation of metal/metal oxide nanoparticles, promoting uniform distribution of electroactive species immobilized onto their surfaces. Recently, Liu et al. prepared Pt nanoparticles (PtNPs) immobilized on PEDOT microspheres (PEDOT-MSs), and applied them to glucose sensing-based GOx.459 Figure 50-1 illustrates the fabrication of the enzyme hybrid conductive composite. PEDOT-MSs were constructed by a CaCO3 micosphere template-assisted polymerization of EDOT monomer under chemical oxidation before removal of the template with ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid (EDTA). Typically, PEDOT has a poor solubility and processability and hinders the conjugation/immoblization of water-soluble enzymes (i.e., GOx). Thus, the preparation process of PEDOT-MSs here consists of two key steps: mild oxidation and advanced oxidation. The former step forms a primary network of CP, which typically has insufficient polymer density caused by a simultaneous outward diffusion of the monomer from the CaCO3 template. The latter step allows the replenishment of new monomers within the template, enabling further polymerization to reinforce the preexisting polymer network that leads to a stable microsphere structure. Here, the anchored PtNPs act as the catalytic sites for H2O2 oxidation that is generated from the enzymatic detection of GOx while PEDOT-MSs with rough surface (Figure 50-2a) serve as a conducting support with a highly effective surface area for Pt nanoparticle formation and electrostatic adsorption of GOx. Uniform PtNPs with a diameter of ∼55 nm were uniformly distributed onto the PEDOT-MS’s surface (Figure 50-2b). A slightly blurry surface of the as-prepared microsphere was observed after electrostatic adsorption of GOx in which the nanoparticles remained stable on the surface. The enzyme hybrid conductive composite-modified screen-printed carbon electrode was successfully applied to glucose sensing with good electroanalytical performance and stability. Nonconducting polymeric nanofibers prepared through electrospinning are also of interest to serve as a host matrix and accommodate electroactive species to provide electrochemical activity as demonstrated by Mercante and colleagues.164 Here, the authors electrospun polyamide 6/ poly(allylamine hydrochloride) (PA6/PAH) nanofibers onto ITO electrodes and functionalized the nanofibers with acidtreated multiwalled carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs) through adsorption (Figure 51-1a,2). The strong binding between
MWCNTs and PA6/PAH nanofibers was expected to occur via H-bonding and/or electrostatic interactions. Specifically, the amide and amine groups available in PA6 and PAH, respectively, contribute hydrogen bonds to the carboxyl groups from the MWCNTs. In addition, PAH can electrostatistically interact with the partially negatively charged MWCNTs at pH 5.0. The resulting strong binding of MWCNTs to the nanofibers not only enhanced the electrochemical signal for DA detection over bare ITO electrode (Figure 51-1b) but also provided a stable signal for 100 CV cycles (Figure 51-3).
5.2.3. Applications for Signal Enhancement (Examples). Signal enhancement in electrochemical biosensing can be realized via two main strategies: first, employing high performance transducers enabling effective interactions and electron transfer between the analyte and electrode, or, second, amplifying the signal responses per each biorecognition binding event. For the former strategy, nanomaterials and nanostructures can be employed as powerful transducers that enable efficient mass transport toward the electrode attributed by nonplanar diffusion, high surface-to-volume ratio, and the reduction of capacitive current due to their nanosize. For the latter strategy, alternatively, nanomaterials can act as labeling carriers and catalysts to amplify current responses.
5.2.3.1. Transducers. Electrically conductive porous nanomaterials and nanostructure in the 3-D form have shown their capability as a powerful interface in electrochemical biosensing, especially for voltammetry based biosensors. Excellent examples of recent years are provided here. Traditional GCEs were modified with a nanoporous gold film (npAuF) to enhance the GCE’s catalytic performance. Zhu et al. demonstrated the enhanced electrochemical capabilities of this modified electrode and used it for the detection of bisphenol A (BPA).460 The release of BPA, a monomer used for PC synthesis, from food/drink containers and packages leads to human health concerns as BPA can disturb the human endocrine system and is associated with obesity, neurotoxicity, and cancer. The authors demonstrated that direct oxidation of BPA using npAuF/GCE outperforms the bare GCE and bulk gold disk electrodes as evidently seen by the lower oxidation potential and higher current intensity (23-fold and 9-fold higher than GCE and bulk gold disk electrodes, respectively). By modifying the npAuF/GCE with a BPA-specific aptamer, high selectivity for BPA vs other chemical species with structures and functional groups similar to BPA was achieved. The fabricated aptamer/npAuF/GCE sensor yielded a detection limit down to 56 pM, which is 15- fold better than that of aptamer/AuNPs/GCE. The remarkable sensitivity was attributed to the excellent catalytic property of npAuF toward the redox reaction of BPA and the immense surface area of 3-D nanoporous electrode which could facilitate the electron transfer and analyte diffusion. The integration of enzymes into electrodes has long been the most sensitive and selective strategy for the detection of biomarkers, metabolites, and coproducts of the biological metabolism. In recent years, nonenzymatic electrochemical detection approaches have gained again attention for the detection of the important analyte H2O2 as metal nanoparticles offer low cost and sufficient stability when compared to enzymes. However, nanomaterial-based nonenzymatic sensors typically exhibit lower sensitivity than those of enzymatic sensors with reported detection limits in the micromolar range. Xi et al. recently demonstrated a H2O2 sensor based on Pdnanoparticles-decorated double-shell-structured N-doped gra-
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.8b00172 Chem. Rev. 2019, 119, 120−194
161
phene quantum dots (NGQDs) and N-doped carbon (NdC) hollow nanospheres (HNSs) as shown in Figure 52-1, and demonstrated their utility in electrochemical detection of extracellular H2O2 molecules released from living cancer cells (Figure 52-2).461 The synergistic effect from the structural and compositional merits of catalytically active species and the HNS offered a high surface area, efficient electron transfer, and high electrocatalytic activity for H2O2, enabling the detection limit at the nanomolar level with a wide dynamic detection range (6 orders of magnitude). In addition, the NGQD@ NdC@Pd HNS hybrid material can promote the electro-
chemical reduction reaction of H2O2 at a potential of 0 V, which will help in avoiding electrode fouling and generation of faradaic interference from electroactive species in physiological samples. The authors have proven that the sensor was able to monitor H2O2 released from U87 cells upon triggering by Nformylmethionyl-leucyl-phenylalanine (fMLP), an artificial stimulator for irritating living cells to release reactive oxygen species, as shown in Figure 52-2iii. Addition of catalase, a H2O2 scavenger, resulted in a decrease of the amperometric current to the background level due to the decomposition of H2O2 by catalase. Furthermore, the authors successfully
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.8b00172 Chem. Rev. 2019, 119, 120−194
162
demonstrated the sensor’s potential in monitoring the decrease of the H2O2 level after radiotherapy treatment, implying that it induces accumulation of reactive oxygen species which eventually triggers cell death (Figure 52-2iv). 5.2.3.2. Labeling. Well-dispersed nanomaterials with high loading capacity, e.g. nanovesicles, mesoporous silica nanoparticles, and GO, are interesting for electrochemical biosensors as they can serve as nanocarriers loaded with electrochemical markers, affording a huge signal increase per binding event. At the same time, their large surface area and available functional groups enable an efficient conjugation of bioreceptors to the nanomaterials’ surfaces. Simple, mesoporous silica particles are an excellent example for this strategy. Lai et al. have shown that these nanospheres possess nanosized pores that are suitable to trap redox active molecules such as TH and developed a highly sensitive electrochemical immunoassay by using the nanospheres for signal enhancement.462 Realizing that clinical immunoassays typically require a highly sensitive platform to detect low abundant protein markers (as there is no simple strategy to multiply proteins for detection as it is common for nucleic acid based assays), signal enhancement is the only strategy to truly lower the limits of detection while avoiding more sample preparation steps. Thus, they synthesized a TH-doped mesoporous silica nanosphere (MSN)/polydopamine (PDA) nanocomposite through a one-pot loading of TH and in situ formation of PDA coating on MSN to protect TH from leaking. These nanospheres were conjugated with antibodies and were employed as signal tracers of sandwich immunoassays in a magnetic bead based platform. After specific sandwich capture with the target protein (human IgG), the PDA coating was destroyed to release the TH markers, which were then detected electrochemically at a CNT-modified electrode by DPV. The authors accomplished a detection limit of 5.8 pg/mL and a linear range over 4 orders of magnitude. Similar strategies based on using mesoporous nanospheres as signal amplifiers for electrochemical immunoassays have been widely reported in which typically electroactive markers, coating, and controlled-release methods vary.463,464
Signal amplification through nanomaterials can also be achieved for EIS.465−467 For example, Wan et al. employed AuNPs for a signal amplification for the detection of E. coli O157:H7 cells.468 Herein, the AuNPs were electrostatically adsorbed to the negative charges of captured bacteria. High loading of AuNPs on the bacterial surface and their ability to act as electron transfer (ET) pathways resulted in a significant reduction of electron transfer resistance (Ret) between the [Fe(CN)6]
3−/4− redox probe in the solution and the substrate gold surface (Figure 53-1), resulting in a larger signal-to-noise ratio (Figure 53-2) when compared to the same setup but without AuNPs. 5.2.3.3. Catalysts. Metal nanoparticles are known as effective catalysts. They can serve as a nanolabel-mediated signal amplifier in which the nanoparticles promote deposition of electroactive markers, e.g. silver, resulting in dramatic enlargement of signal generation. AuNPs-catalyzed silver deposition is known as a strategy for electrochemical signal amplification, specially coupled with anodic stripping analysis. Alternatively, AuNRs possess properties similar to AuNPs but offer a larger surface area which hence can increase catalytic and silver deposition sites. Recently, Zhang et al. have applied AuNRs as a nanocatalyst label for silver deposition in an electrochemical immuno-
assay.469 The signal enhancement was obtained from additional self-assembled AuNRs via chemical linker (1,6- hexanedithiol) after sandwich capturing of the analyte between the immobilized antibody and a first AuNR reporter probe (Figure 54). Multiple cycles of AuNR assembly could be
performed to increase the number of catalytic and nucleation sites for labeling. In this work, the fourth assembling cycle provided 5.8-fold higher silver stripping current in comparison to the signals obtained from only using the first AuNRs sandwiched immunocomplex. A detection limit of 0.08 fg mL−1 and a large linear range of 6 orders of magnitude were reported. Si and co-workers have proposed a powerful electrochemical label based on biocatalysts consisting of ALP-incorporated AuNCs (ALP-AuNCs).144 They have applied it toward the detection of microRNAs (miRNAs), which are short noncoding RNA molecules (18−25 nucleotides) and are useful biomarkers as they regulate genes that are relevant to diseases such as cancer, viral infections, and neurological diseases. The level of miRNAs in blood can therefore serve as a biomarker in cancer diagnostics. Their low expression levels, reasonably short and not highly diverse nucleotide sequence, and background interferences make quantification of free miRNAs in blood extremely difficult and hence a good model analyte to demonstrate the performance of Si’s ALP-AuNCs. ALP is known to catalyze the hydrolysis of substrates such as ascorbic acid 2-phosphate (AA-p). The product can then act as a reducing agent for silver. AuNCs trapped inside ALP can also serve as a catalyst to induce the silver deposition reaction and enhance the overall reaction. The established nanoprobes provided a detection limit for free miRNAs determined in blood as low as 21.5 aM and were able to identify single-base mutant levels in miRNAs. Figure 55-1 displays a schematic illustration of the detection strategy. The investigation of electroanalytical performances of the silver deposition based assays for miRNAs using the ALP-AuNCs-labeled detection DNA probes is shown in Figure 55-2. The binding of two DNA probes (P1 and P2) complementary to the targets could increase the binding strength and capacity of ALP-AuNCslabeled DNA detection probes. Zheng and colleagues discovered an intrinsic catalytic activity of Fe3O4 nanoparticles toward the electrochemical
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.8b00172 Chem. Rev. 2019, 119, 120−194
163
reduction of small dye molecules, such as TH.140 The authors constructed a high performance nanoprobe by modifying Fe3O4 nanoparticles with metallic nanocages, acting as an efficient signal amplifier. The negatively charged Ag−Pd nanocages were electrostatically adsorbed onto Fe3O4 beads that were previously coated with a positively charged polymer, poly(diallyldimethylammonium chloride) (PDDA). Compared to the enzymatic peroxidase/H2O2 system for electrochemical signal generation, the proposed hybrid nanoparticle labels are more robust and stable in a wide pH and temperature range. The nonenzymatic nanoelectrocatalyst was further conjugated to SYL3C aptamers that specifically recognize the EpCAM and was used as a label for ultrasensitive detection of cancer cells (MCF-7) as shown in Figure 56. 5.2.4. Other Potential Applications. 5.2.4.1. Multiplexed Sensing. Metallic and semiconducting nanoparticles have been successfully used as nanoprobes for multiplex detection, in particular coupled with stripping analysis due to their inherent unique electrochemical fingerprint.470 The distinctive redox potential from various type of nanoparticles allows for encoding of the analyte being tagged.471,472 For example, Zhou et al. recently employed mesoporous silica nanoparticles loaded with CdSeTe@CdS quantum dots (QDs) or with AgNCs and used these two particles as signal probes for simultaneous detection of B-cell lymphoma 2 (Bcl-2) and Bcl-
2-associated X protein (Bax) (Figure 57).209 The level of these two proteins plays a key role in monitoring the apoptosis of tumor cells and evaluating the effect of cancer drugs, in which Bcl-2 is an antiapoptotic factor, and Bax is a proapoptotic factor. The tumor cells undergo apoptosis when excess Bax proteins are present and vice versa. In ref 209, the authors demonstrated the proof-of-principle for multiplexing using their metallic nanoparticles by applying it to the study of apoptosis of K562 cells. Here, the cells were treated with nilotinib, a potential drug for the cancer treatment. The Bax/Bcl-2 ratio was increased when the drug dosage and incubation time increased, indicating the apoptosis of K562 cells. Their biosensor can reduce errors that result from separated detection of the proteins in different samples and also provided a low detection limit (∼0.5 fmol or ∼1 × 103 cells) for simultaneous detection of Bcl-2 and Bax protein expressions, which makes their system a viable option for cancer research. Zhao et al. have applied a similar principle to the simultaneous detection of carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) and α-fetoprotein (AFP) in which shell-encoded AuNPs, including Au@Cu2O and Au@Ag core−shell NPs, were used as the nanotracers in a competitive assay format.473 Herein, Au@Cu2O and Au@Ag were modified with aptamers to recognize CEA and AFP, respectively. The nanoprobes were

then hybridized to the complementary DNA probes immobilized onto a GCE. The presence of CEA and AFP resulted in competitive binding to the hybridized nanoprobes on the GCE, inducing the release of the nanoprobes. The decrease of independent DPV response at −0.08 V (oxidation of Cu+ to Cu2+) and 0.26 V (oxidation of Ag0 to Ag+) was performed to identify and quantify CEA and AFP, respectively. Another interesting strategy for electrochemical multiplexing is the use of nanosurface topography of electrodes, as it allows to differentiate voltammetric peaks resulting from intrinsic electrochemical reactions of analytes (see also section 5.1.4.1). AA, DA, and UA are typically copresent in biological samples and exhibit similar oxidative peaks and hence make simultaneous detection of the three analytes challenging;474 especially the AA peak can be hindered by a DA peak. DA and UA typically possess the capability to adsorb on electrode surfaces475,476 and are, therefore, able to generate voltammetric responses similar to those obtained through stripping analysis. In 2014, Punckt and co-workers demonstrated that modified gold electrodes with porous drop-cast functionalized graphene
sheets (FGS) created a nanoporous structure which induced the simultaneous detection of AA, UA, and DA.286 The authors demonstrated the comparative study of the voltammetric peaks resulting from the gold electrodes modified with nanoporous FGS, monolayer FGS (FGS-ML), and a bare glassy carbon electrode (GC) as shown in Figure 58. Interestingly, the
electrode modified with FGS-ML does not exhibit superior voltammetric peaks over GC (Figure 58-1). However, bare GCs were not able to distinguish between the oxidative peaks generated from AA, DA, and UA as determined by linear sweep voltammetry (LSV), whereas three distinctive multiple peaks were observed at the electrode modified with nanoporous FGS (Figure 58-2). The electrode modified with nanoporous FGS having a total accessible pore volume of 21 nL generated two oxidative peaks for AA at around −80 and +50 mV vs Ag/AgCl. The authors suggested that the LSV peak at −80 mV should be attributed to a thin-film-diffusion response due to pore depletion while the response at +50 mV
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.8b00172 Chem. Rev. 2019, 119, 120−194
166
should be correlated to the effective diffusion-limited response owing to an increase of the number of electroactive sites per geometric surface area (effective catalytic activity). The increase of total pore volumes to 41 and 102 nL resulted in higher surface area, which consequently resulted in an increase of the signal intensities by more than 1 order of magnitude. 5.2.4.2. Mixing. In microfluidic electrochemical biosensors, rapid and homogeneous mixing of reagents is of importance to ensure efficient reactions, i.e. binding of analytes to the bioreceptors. However, the intrinsic laminar flow inside microfluidic systems makes mixing a challenge. Integration of a passive mixer, a mixing process that relies on a geometric design without external input, to the microfluidic system can improve the mixing efficiency. Our research group has recently demonstrated the capability of electrospun nanofiber mats in the enhancement of passive mixing in microfluidic systems.349 We integrated electrospun nanofiber mats into Y-shaped PMMA microchannels (Figure 59-1) and evaluated the degree
of mixing by fluorescence microscopy and ImageJ analysis. The fiber mats with smaller nanofiber diameter (450−500 nm) yielded a greater mixing degree than that of microfibers (0.8− 2.7 μm in diameter). The significant inhomogeneity in pore size and distribution of the nanofiber mats plays a big role in the mixing performance. In addition, the mixing capability is dependent on nanofiber mat height but it is independent of nanofiber mat length, suggesting that most mixing occurs as fluid enters and exits the fiber mat (Figure 59-2). The investigation clearly implies that when nanofiber mats are used in electrochemical microfluidic systems as an immobilization
surface and/or a transducer the inherent passive mixing performance can be synergistically achieved. Even though a passive mixer bears favorable advantages such as no external input required and low cost, flexible control of mixing is unlikely to be achieved because the flow pattern is predefined. Active mixers, by which the flow is perturbed through an external output, are therefore an alternative option. Zhou et al. fabricated a microfluidic chip with PDMS micropillar embedded MNPs to serve as an active mixer as shown in Figure 60.477 When the magnetic field is off, namely “MF OFF”, the micropillars stay vertically in the initial state; thus the mixing efficiency is governed only by diffusion. However, when a magnetic field is applied, termed “MF ON”, it induces a reorientation of the PDMS micropillars owing to their inherent elasticity, thus promoting highly efficient mixing of the passing fluids. Three sizes of micropillar pitch (P), i.e. 35, 25, and 15 μm, were studied. It was shown that the greatest mixing was achieved at the smallest pitch.

sections.heading: 5.3. Integration of Nanomaterials or Nanostructures into Microfluidic Systems
sections.text:
In this section, we will focus our discussion on the integration of nanomaterials or nanostructures to serve as components in microfluidic devices, such as transducers, separators, and mixer. In some instances, electrochemical strategies even assist in the generation of the nanomaterials such as for seed-mediated growth, electrodeposition, and electropolymerization as detailed below.
5.3.1. In Situ Integration Strategy. In situ integration of nanomaterials and nanostructures based strategy encompasses those processes that allow the generation of nanomaterials/ nanostructures directly onto the device substrate, and consequently do not require a subsequent transfer process. These techniques include mainly lithography-based nanomaterial/nanostructure fabrication (section 5.3.1.1), seed-mediated growth (section 5.3.1.2), electrochemical deposition (section 5.3.1.3), and the combination of lithography and one of the latter two techniques (section 5.3.1.4).
5.3.1.1. Lithography-Based Nanomaterial/Nanostructure Fabrication. Traditional lithographic approaches are used to pattern substrates in a top-down manner that involves protecting the desired area by a patterned photomask and selectively lifting-off material in undesired areas by a mechanical or chemical etching process. The technique enables mass production and precise control over the length and position of the fabricated nanomaterials. It has been very popular for 1-D nanomaterial fabrication such as nanowires (Figure 61-1) and nanopillars448 (Figure 61-2). Additionally, nanoporous structures inside a microfluidic channel can be generated via lithography (Figure 61-3).496
5.3.1.2. Seed-Mediated Growth. The technique is a bottom-up approach which typically applies for the growth of 1-D nanomaterials such as CNTs,500,501 nanorods,502 and nanospikes.416,503 In general, metal catalysts are first deposited onto a substrate of choice, followed by a growing process that can be realized either through CVD or through hydrothermal growth. The former technique requires costly and sophisticated instrumentation but provides high quality products and can be controlled well. On the other hand, the latter technique, chemical solution growth induced formation of nanomaterials, is significantly less expensive and requires only simple instrumentation. One-dimensional nanomaterials are generated
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.8b00172 Chem. Rev. 2019, 119, 120−194
167
also with high quality and small diameters but typically only with a low production yield. CVD has also been used to fabricate single (Figure 62-1a)504 or parallel SWNTs (Figure 62-1b)505 at desired locations to form transducers in microfluidic systems. Sansuk et al. integrated the CVD SWNT network grown on a silicon substrate into an electrochemical microfluidic device for DA detection by flow injection analysis (FIA) based amperometry.506 Their proposed fabrication technique is depicted in
Figure 62-2. Similarly, Seo et al. have fabricated SWNTs on silicon pillars coated with catalyst particles by CVD as shown in Figure 62-3.507
Hydrothermally grown titanium dioxide (TiO2) nanorods were presented by Qiu et al. The nanorods were grown on a flat Si substrate in a microchannel, modified with an antiEpCAM antibody and used to capture and isolate CTCs.502
Figure 63-1a illustrates the in situ formation of TiO2 nanorod arrays on the flat Si substrate. First, the substrate was coated with a TiO2 seed layer followed by hydrothermal growth of the nanorod arrays. The TiO2 nanorod arrays were then covered by a PDMS channel containing two holes for entrance and exit of the solution. The TiO2 nanorod arrays were modified with the antibodies directly in the microfluidic device by sequentially flowing binding reagents, streptavidin, and the biotinylated anti-EpCAM antibody. In order to further increase the likelihood of cell−array contact, the authors also employed Si micropillars as a substrate for TiO2 nanorod growth with the same synthesis method (Figure 63-1b). The added nanorodmodified Si micropillars provided 30% increase in recovery yield. While no electrochemical detection was integrated into this cell-capture device, it can easily be envisioned to function in a manner similar to some of the other sample preparation methods discussed previously.
Li et al. have also exploited the hydrothermal growth process to synthesize zinc oxide (ZnO) nanowire onto a carbon electrode coated with ZnO nanoparticles to generate a WE in an electrochemical microfluidic paper-based analytical device (EμPAD) as shown in Figure 63-2.503 Here, the WE is positioned on a separate layer underneath a layer containing
the reaction zone, CE, and RE in order to perform the hydrothermal growth of ZnO NWs on the carbon WE without affecting the other electrodes in the system.
5.3.1.3. Electrochemical Deposition. Electrochemical deposition is an old electroanalytical technique that allows for a bottom-up approach to generate nanomaterials/nanostructures directly on the electrodes by simply applying a potential to the electrode. This induces the electrochemical reduction of metal ions or monomers, forming nanomaterials that adhere directly to the electrode surface. The integration of the nanomaterials/ nanostructures through electrochemical deposition can be conveniently performed either before508 or after device assembly509,510 (Figure 64-1). Also single nanowires can be made through electrodeposition. Ramanathan et al. generated a nanowire from CPs, e.g. PANI and PPy, through a single-step electrodeposition (Figure 64-2).252 Typically, the monomer solution is dropped between two electrodes. Electropolymerization of the monomer is then performed in galvanostatic mode by applying a desired current. The feasibility to control chemical composition, location, and alignment makes the electrodeposition technique highly promising to generate individual nanowires in microfluidic biosensor systems as demonstrated in ref 511. The electrodeposition technique is very simple, fast, controllable, and inexpensive but is not yet suitable for mass production.
5.3.1.4. Advanced Techniques Utilizing Lithographic Strategies. Nanolithography coupled with CVD and electrochemical deposition has been employed to create highly ordered arrays of nanomaterials/nanostructures as shown in Figure 65. Kim et al. integrated MWNTs into an electrochemical microfluidic system by using electron beam (E-beam) nanolithography, thin-film metal deposition, CVD, and reactive/electrochemical etching as shown in Figure 65-1.512 E-beam nanolithography was used to generate nanoholes (97 ± 10 nm diameter and 75−80 nm depth) for Ni catalyst deposition (30 nm) realized by an electron beam evaporator. After lifting off the protective layer, the MWNTs were synthesized onto the as-grown Ni catalysts by plasma enhanced
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.8b00172 Chem. Rev. 2019, 119, 120−194
168
CVD. In order to passivate the sidewalls of the MWNTs,
silicon dioxide was deposited onto the wafer by CVD using
tetraethylorthosilicate (TEOS). The MWNT tips were opened
by chemical mechanical polishing (CMP), rendering carboxylic
acid groups on the tips for further conjugation with DNA
probes.
Similarly, Kim and co-workers fabricated nanohole arrays by nanolithography in order to construct highly ordered arrays of gold nanocups that were formed by simple electrodeposition.508 Here, photoresist nanopatterned ITO was used as a substrate for electrodeposition of gold chloride in the presence of surfactants. The electrodeposition time plays an important role in controlling the obtained nanostructure; i.e. a short
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.8b00172 Chem. Rev. 2019, 119, 120−194
169
deposition time (60 s) exhibited thin-film-like structures (Figure 65-2c_ii) while a longer deposition time (240 s) provided cup-like structures (Figure 65-2c_iii), which ultimately influenced the electrochemical sensitivity toward DA detection (5 times higher sensitivity could be obtained from the nanocup electrode arrays). 5.3.2. Ex Situ Based Strategy. This strategy refers to the
integration processes that rely on introducing as-prepared nanomaterials/nanostructures to device substrates.
5.3.2.1. Nanomaterial Integration without Host Support. 5.3.2.1.1. Drop-Casting and Dip-Coating. Drop-casting and dip-coating are the simplest and most inexpensive, yet highly efficient strategies to integrate nanomaterials with electrode surfaces. They have been widely applied with colloidal nanomaterials such as metal nanoparticles, CNTs, GO, and graphene-like 2-D materials in order to modify electrodes in electrochemical microfluidic biosensors (Figure 66-1).513,514 In FET-based microfluidic biosensors the as-grown nanowires are typically drop-casted onto a favorable substrate,515 followed by
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.8b00172 Chem. Rev. 2019, 119, 120−194
170
postaddressing source and drain contact pads onto both ends of the nanowire by lithography (Figure 66-2).516
5.3.2.1.2. Field-Assisted Assembly. In the case of fieldassisted assembly, a controllable external force, e.g. magnetic and electric fields, is applied in order to locate nanomaterials at a desired location, typically between or onto the electrical contact areas.517−519 For example, Herrasti et al. attached SWNTs onto the surface of magnetic particles (MPs) and confined the MP/SWNT composite onto the Pt WE. By removal of the magnetic field, the MPs/SWNTs are released and the electrode can easily be cleaned and reused (Figure 67- 1).517 In another approach, Li and co-workers have fabricated a microfluidic device containing gold array contact pads and applied an electric field to assemble SWNTs across the electrodes after flowing the solution of SWNTs into the channel (Figure 67-2).519 A small potential drop of 0.5−2 V
can be observed from the oscilloscope when the SWNT bridges between the two electrodes are formed.
5.3.2.1.3. Printing. Inkjet Printing. With the advancement of printing technology nowadays520 the inkjet-printing modality has become popular and is highly suitable for integrating nanomaterials onto flexible substrates, e.g. paper and plastic films with mass-production capability. Colloidal nanomaterials such as metal nanoparticles/nanowires, CNT, and graphene can be directly used as an ink and conveniently patterned with desirable electrode configuration.521,522 In the past few years a significant amount of research has focused on the development of nanomaterial ink compositions that provides the best printing quality as well as adhesion and hence stability on the substrates.523 The inkjet printing of nanomaterials has become a promising technology that enables electrochemical biosensors to meet requirements in real-world applications, especially due to their affordable production cost with
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.8b00172 Chem. Rev. 2019, 119, 120−194
171
massive-fabrication capability. Figure 68 illustrates devices integrated with nanomaterials by inkjet printing. Screen Printing. Similar to inkjet-printing-based technology, screen printing has been applied to the integration of nanomaterials to miniaturized devices.526 In comparison to inkjet printing, however, the technique commonly requires a greater amount of ink in order to produce uniform films over the entire substrate. Mixing nanomaterials with screen-printed ink to fabricate electrode nanocomposites has been reported to overcome the problem,527 but it is still not an easy task to achieve good dispersibility between the nanomaterials and the ink paste.528 In addition, the flexibility of electrode designs is lower in comparison to inkjet printing because the technique needs a block screen containing the electrode pattern, which has to be designed and patterned prior to the screen printing. Microcontact Printing. Microcontact printing relies on stamping nanomaterial ink assisted by a patterned PDMS onto a surface of a desired substrate. This technique is frequently used to create self-assembled monolayers on gold electrode surfaces and has even been used to print cells onto surfaces. Santhanam and Andres have successfully applied the technique to fabricate uniform arrays of AuNPs (Figure 69).529
5.3.2.1.4. Pressed Transfer. Pressed transfers refer to a process of transferring nanomaterials from a donor substrate to
a target substrate. Escarpa’s research group have used it to coat SWNTs530 and carbon black nanoparticles531,532 on PMMA substrates and coupled to microfluidic chips as an end-channel transducer. The technique relies on preparing homogeneous nanomaterial films on a Teflon filter membrane and pressing the film onto a PMMA substrate (Figure 70-1). Georgakilas et al. have proposed that the compression of carbon nanomaterials enables significant enhancement of electrical conductivity of the carbon film.533 The technique is also highly suitable to be applied to nanofiber mats (Figure 70-2).495
5.3.2.2. Nanomaterial Integration with Host Support. Functional nanomaterials, e.g. nanoparticles and short nanofibers, have been fixed to a solid support prior to their
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.8b00172 Chem. Rev. 2019, 119, 120−194
172
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.8b00172 Chem. Rev. 2019, 119, 120−194
173
integration into microfluidic systems in order to enhance their stability and distribution inside the microchannel. The nanomaterials can be embedded inside or adsorbed onto the supports which are chosen to enhance and maintain the functionality of the nanomaterials after integration. Functional nanomaterials acting as nanocatalysts and electron transfer promoters, or as immobilization support, have mostly been adsorbed onto the surface of the electrically conductive support in order to leverage their benefits and have efficient contact with the analyte. Graphene foam, an electrically conductive 3-D porous structure, exhibits excellent conductivity, high surface area,
and a surface chemistry that is favorable for accommodating a large number of functional groups inside the microchannel. However, graphene foam typically has a thickness in the range of millimeters which makes the integration process very challenging. Ali et al. have physically adsorbed short TiO2 nanofibers onto the surface of graphene foam to serve as a transducer and immobilization surface for bioreceptors, and proposed the strategy for integrating the composite (1.2 mm) into a PDMS−glass hybrid microfluidic chip438 as shown in
Figure 71-1. Here, the functionalized graphene foam is located on the PDMS channel side and opposite to the gold CE and Ag/AgCl RE fabricated on the glass slide. The PDMS channel contained a hole allowing for electrical connection of T-shape graphene foam from outside of the chip after sealing the hole with epoxy. More recently, the same group also proposed an in situ integration of graphene foam assisted by liquid-phase photopolymerization (Figure 71-2).332 The graphene foam was placed on the gold WE and located at the same side of the gold CE and Ag/AgCl RE. In this technique, a spacer with the same height as the graphene foam was used to separate the bottom electrode piece and the top glass containing inlet and outlet holes. The cavity between the spacer was filled with a photopolymer. After exposure to UV light through a photomask, the unexposed area, indicating unpolymerized polymer, was removed by ethanol, leaving highly porous graphene foam embedded in the microfluidic channel.
PDMS is an elastomer that has long been used for the fabrication of microfluidic chips188 and used as a stamp as described above. It has also been employed as a host support assisting the integration of nanomaterials into microfluidic systems. For example, Kang and co-workers embedded CNTs in a PDMS surface and developed a DNA sensor (Figure 72- 1).534 They first fabricated Pd/Au electrodes on SiO2 substrates coated with methyl (−CH3)-terminated octadecyl-
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.8b00172 Chem. Rev. 2019, 119, 120−194
174
trichlorosilane (OTS), a release layer. Then, a photoresist layer was patterned to open up a specific area for CNT adsorption. After pouring and curing of PDMS on the as-prepared substrate, the adsorbed CNTs and the Pd/Au electrodes were released and fixed onto the PDMS layer. In a similar approach, microcontact printing was used for the patterning of CNTs prior to their transfer to PDMS.535
In a unique sample-preparation approach, Zhou et al. embedded MNPs inside PDMS micropillars by the procedure shown in Figure 72-2 and used it as an active micromixer inside a microfluidic system (see also section 5.2.4).477
Electrospun nanofiber mats are an alternative candidate to serve as a host support for the integration of nanomaterials into microfluidic systems (Figure 73). A wide variety of electroactive nanomaterials can be decorated into or onto the fiber mats with high stability and uniformity, promoting the utilization of the nanomaterials inside microfluidic systems. Moreover, our research group has successfully demonstrated that electrospun nanofibers can be simply integrated into polymer-based microfluidic systems to serve as functional modules such as sensing elements,536 immobilization support,348 and mixers.349 This is highly promising to advance the field of electrochemical microfluidic biosensors and nanomaterials.
All mentioned techniques are summarized in Table 6.

sections.heading: 6. CHALLENGES AND FUTURE POTENTIAL
sections.text:
Electrochemical biosensors and their miniaturized LOCs are developed to answer some of the toughest analytical challenges. Ideal biosensors are sought to detect low abundance analytes in their original matrix from a minuscule volume with rapid, precise, and accurate results, remain stable under any environmental and assay circumstances, and provide all of this at low costs and with easy assay procedures. Detection modes of in vivo, inline, online, ex situ, and remote, of continuous monitoring to single use, are typical for their application; biocompatibility, no toxicity, and powerless operation are some of the more advanced features that can be required. Each of these desirable characteristics and capabilities poses a scientific challenge that must be addressed. Many of these requirements have been solved for a specific analyte, with the prime example being the glucose sensor. Numerous biosensors have been described, operationally demonstrated, and commercialized that combined fulfill all of these requirements. However, it should be kept in mind that glucose is not a low abundance analyte, and that biosensor research on this analyte started in 1962 with Leland Clark’s famous first published glucose biosensor,1 resulting in more
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.8b00172 Chem. Rev. 2019, 119, 120−194
175
than 50 years of research efforts by now. Thus, the desired characteristics and capabilities of biosensors remain scientific challenges for most analytes of interest. This review showcases how functional nanomaterials can assist in the amelioration or even solving of these challenges
when applied in electrochemical biosensors as transducers, for signal generation or enhancement, for immobilization, or for sample preparation (see also summary in Table 5). Yet, the integration of nanomaterials is also accompanied by numerous new challenges, unique to the respective materials of choice. Specifically, when used in an electrochemical biosensor, the nanomaterial must be stable and function under physiological conditions: it must tolerate high ionic strength buffers, demonstrate good performance at room or body temperatures, in aqueous solutions and under ambient air, and remain stable for hours under these conditions, if not days and weeks. These challenges can be solved with proper surface modifications, but they are mandatory requirements and must be developed for each new nanomaterial of interest. Often a balance must be found between preserving the functionality of the nanomaterial and its preparation for use under physiological conditions. For example, when lipid nanovesicles are used for signal enhancement by entrapping electrochemically active marker molecules, the lipid bilayer must be made rigid to withstand osmolality differences during an assay and to remain stable without leakage during months of storage, and they must carry surface moieties that assist in avoiding aggregation (such as through polyethylene glycol or simply through charged lipid headgroups). These stable nanovesicles can then only be lysed with the help of harsh methods (detergents, organic solvent, ultrasonication, boiling), which adds a new demand for the electrochemical biosensor assay protocol as the release of the electrochemical interior markers is needed for signal generation. [See also section 5.1.4.3.] Another example is 0- D nanoparticles which typically require surface coatings to remain colloidally stable even in buffered solutions. For AuNPs, this has long been solved using, for example, citric acid as surface ligand. Other inorganic nanoparticles often require a polymer coating or a silica shell which significantly alters their surface properties. Yet, silver nanoparticles are preferably stored under inert, dark, and cold conditions.540 Strategies that focus on the growth of thin shells will be of great interest in the future, because (1) they increase the overall size minimally in contrast to polymer coatings, (2) they can serve toward stabilization of the nanomaterial, decrease leakage, hence decrease toxicity, and increase long-term stability, and (3) add functionality if desired. When the nanomaterial is directly associated with the biorecognition or analyte molecules in the electrochemical biosensor, e.g. when it is used for signal generation, immobilization, or analyte isolation, functional moieties must be available on the nanomaterial surface that allow for the gentle coupling chemistries needed with biorecognition molecules (most frequently used are NHS/EDC chemistry, glutaraldehyde, silane chemistry, thiol chemistry, and in some instances Cu-free click chemistry). No harsh coupling chemistry is applicable. This adds a constraint in the design of new functional nanomaterials and ultimately leads to the formation of multifunctional materials in which the development of the proper surface chemistry and the inherent desired functionality made for application in sensing should be of equal importance. Thiol, amine, aldehyde, and carboxylic acid groups are likely also the best contestants in the future. With the increased research into binding peptides,541,542 it would also be of interest to have those, biotin, or short peptide nucleic acid probes available as coupling groups on nanomaterials. An immense surface-to-volume ratio is a major advantage that nanomaterials offer to electrochemical biosensors. This
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.8b00172 Chem. Rev. 2019, 119, 120−194
176
large surface area leads to their superior performance in comparison to bulk materials in immobilization, in analyte isolation/separation and as transducer material. However, it is also accompanied by its major disadvantage: the more surface is available the more surface fouling and nonspecific binding can occur, and nonspecific signals can be generated. Thus, while the overall signal intensity may be significantly increased, the truly relevant signal-to-noise ratios may not, which is a major problem seldom discussed in material-focused publications. Thus, the challenge is to synthesize and functionalize these nanomaterials with biosensor applications in real-world matrixes (and not distilled water, buffer, or even organic solvents) in mind. A step forward in this direction is the combination of functional nanomaterial development and antifouling property studies. Especially polymers as polymer brushes, with nanofibers, for example with polyethylene glycol coatings, have demonstrated excellent antifouling behavior, and surface charges can assist in preventing undesired binding events.543−546
Biosensors are sought to be low-cost analytical devices, so functional nanomaterials used within the sensors, by definition, must also be inexpensive in their productionand inexpensive in their integration. Upscaling production of reliable synthesis, fabrication, and functionalization of nanomaterials must be solved to avoid intolerable variances between lots, which is really a universal requirement for nanomaterials independent of the application field. Furthermore, when used as transducer or sample preparation material, the actual reliable integration within the biosensor or the LOC device must be solved for large-scale production to move these types of biosensors from the lab bench to a commercially viable product. Screen printing, inkjet printing, and traditional bulk coating procedures for blocking reagents such as spotting, spraying, and dip-coating are feasible options. The ultimate question that needs to be asked is whether the new functional nanomaterials are truly needed to improve the performance of an electrochemical biosensor, or whether a sensor that does not use a nanomaterial can perform equally
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.8b00172 Chem. Rev. 2019, 119, 120−194
177

178
well. In some instances the answer is an easy “yes”, as outlined in many examples given in this review and in part summarized in Table 5. Superior behavior of nanomaterials can result directly in improved analytical figures of merit such as limit of detection, precision, accuracy, or specificity. It can also relate to a reduction in assay time due to overcoming diffusion limitations. However, superiority over bulk and macro material can also derive from a sheer dimension-related property. For example, nanosized needles are needed to measure local analytes within a living cell, and no material in macro dimensions can provide such a resolution. Semiconducting nanowires have a highly efficient electron transport and their high surface-area-to-volume ratio and alterable electron transport properties along a confined longitudinal axis facilitate a large change of their electrical properties upon small perturbations.298 The same material in larger dimensions cannot offer the same properties. Yet, it must be stated that too many papers are published that miss solid proof of a nanomaterial’s superior analytical performance or that omit important experiments to demonstrate that the new material can indeed be used under physiological conditions and is stable enough for a successful commercial biosensor development. More interaction between material and analytical scientists is therefore strongly encouraged to improve the outcome and impact nanomaterials have on biosensors as shown for many of the publication references within this review. Thus, what does the future hold for functional nanomaterials in electrochemical biosensors and their associated LOC devices? Undoubtedly, nanomaterials have had as large an impact on these biosensors in the past 10 years as the onset of miniaturization and microfabrication had on the analytical field in the 1990s. Nanomaterials remain to be extensively investigated and developed for biosensor applications. When searching the Web of Science, around 750 K references were found for the term “nano*” for the period 2013−2018 alone. Electrochemistry as a standalone field is among the top 10 fields, analytical chemistry is the top 12th field to appear in such a search. Stated differently, in that same time frame, one of all publications in the field of electrochemistry had the search topic “nano” associated with the record. Judging by the sheer numbers, nanomaterials and nanostructures thus have a large influence on new developments within this field. The articles showcased in this review article are prime examples for the successful synthesis, use, and integration of functional nanomaterials in electrochemical biosensors or LOC devices. Key areas of interest for future fundamental research relate to finding new strategies (1) to increase signal-to-noise ratios, (2) to avoid nonspecific reactions, and (3) to prevent fouling processes. (4) Harnessing responses of BREs through direct interactions with nanomaterials is also especially relevant as biological and man-made materials can be of the same dimension. (5) Can new nanomaterials overcome the centuryold battle against charging current; can they improve electron transfer rates? (6) New strategies for multiplexing similar to those achievable with optical methods are highly desirable. Electrochemistry can easily achieve multiplexing through massively parallelized and locally separated micro/nanoelectrodes. However, achieving multiplexing for tens of analytes through nanomaterial labels that are electrochemically distinguishable within one analysis would be extraordinarily useful.
Key areas of interest for future applied research with respect to functional nanomaterials must focus on issues related (1) to upscaling their synthesis, (2) to studying their long-term stability under ambient or physiological conditions, and (3) to robustly integrating them with biosensors and miniaturized analytical systems. (4) Toxicity/biodegradability assessment of the materials should be mandatory as biosensors are envisioned to be disposable systems used (and hence disposed of) outside of the analytical laboratory or are even used in vivo, broadening the demand for biocompatibility assessment studies as well.

Biographies
Nongnoot Wongkaew received her Ph.D. (biotechnology) in 2013 from King Mongkut’s University of Technology Thonburi, Thailand. After completing her Ph.D., she became a postdoctoral fellow of the Alexander von Humboldt Foundation (2014−2016) and has been working on electrospun functional nanofibers since then at the University of Regensburg, Germany. Currently, she is an assistant professor and leading the nanofiber research group at the Institute of Analytical Chemistry, Chemo- and Biosensors, University of Regensburg. Her research interests include fabrication of functional nanofibers through electrospinning, electrochemical microfluidic devices, and applications toward chemical sensors and biosensors, as well as cell-based analyses.
Marcel Simsek received his bachelor’s degree of applied chemistry from Technische Hochschule Nürnberg Georg Simon Ohm, Germany (2014), and received his master’s degree of chemistry from the University of Regensburg, Germany, in 2017. He joined Prof. Baeumner’s group in 2016, and is currently working towards his Ph.D. His research focuses on electrospun conductive nanofibers for high performance electrochemical sensing.
Christian Griesche received his master of science degree in chemistry in 2017 at the University of Regensburg. He is currently working as a Ph.D. student at the Institute of Analytical Chemistry, Chemo- and Biosensors, at the Department of Chemistry and Pharmacy in Regensburg. His current research focuses on the development of electrochemical microfluidic sensors for bioanalytical applications.
Antje J. Baeumner is a professor of analytical chemistry and Director of the Institute of Analytical Chemistry, Chemo- and Biosensors, at the University of Regensburg, Germany. Before accepting the position in Regensburg, she was a professor of biological engineering and Director of Graduate Studies in the Department of Biological and Environmental Engineering at Cornell University in Ithaca, NY, USA. Her research is focused on the development of micrototal analysis systems and smart lateral flow assays for detection of pathogens and toxins in food and the environment, and for medical diagnostics. Nanomaterials play an important role in her research, including nanoparticles and nanovesicles for signal amplification and nanofibers for immobilization and detection as well as mixing.

metadata.abstractText: Electrochemical biosensors and associated lab-on-a-chip devices are the analytical system of choice when rapid and on-site results are needed in medical diagnostics and food safety, for environmental protection, process control, wastewater treatment, and life sciences discovery research among many others. A premier example is the glucose sensor used by diabetic patients. Current research focuses on developing sensors for specific analytes in these application fields and addresses challenges that need to be solved before viable commercial products can be designed. These challenges typically include the lowering of the limit of detection, the integration of sample preparation into the device and hence analysis directly within a sample matrix, finding strategies for long-term in vivo use, etc. Today, functional nanomaterials are synthesized, investigated, and applied in electrochemical biosensors and lab-on-a-chip devices to assist in this endeavor. This review answers many questions around the nanomaterials used, their inherent properties and the chemistries they offer that are of interest to the analytical systems, and their roles in analytical applications in the past 5 years (2013−2018), and it gives a quantitative assessment of their positive effects on the analyses. Furthermore, to facilitate an insightful understanding on how functional nanomaterials can be beneficial and effectively implemented into electrochemical biosensor-based lab-on-a-chip devices, seminal studies discussing important fundamental knowledge regarding device fabrication and nanomaterials are comprehensively included here. The review ultimately gives answers to the ultimate question: “Are they really needed or can bulk materials accomplish the same?” Finally, challenges and future directions are also discussed.
